The exams were difficult but with practice and the notecard you can have, it is manageable. Quizzes were hard. Homework is graded on completion. Very understanding and caring prof. I would 100% recommend her!!!!

Helen is my favorite professor yet. She is so kind, loves math, and understands her students. She is open to feedback and just wants to be the best for her students. Everything she expects is very clear. Her exams are difficult but no curveballs. Questions may be difficult, but you have the skills to solve them. Highly recommend!

Great professor who cares about her students. She gives time to students who are struggling (Time during lectures to do more examples, loads of office hour times). Homework assigned for each Tuesday and Friday, but if you stay ahead, it is not as much as you think. If you study and make good formula sheets for the test, you will do well on tests.

Professor Wong is awesome! She is easily one of (if not my absolute) favorite professors on campus. She is extremely accessible, and she really wants to make sure that the students understand the material. She is also a very generous grader, both with partial credit and with the curve. On top of all this, she is a genuinely nice and caring person!

She doesn't really teach anything but the basics well. Your best chance for learning is talking with other kids in the class and looking up how to solve problems online. Luckily, the class was curved a good amount so if you put in a lot of work you can get a respectable grade.

Prof Wong is a real gem, a kind-hearted professor who truly cares about her students and wants them to succeed. She makes you work to understand the material and grow an appreciation for it. She was so accessible outside of class/office hours and took extra steps to help me understand concepts and adjust to hard academics.

Professor Thomas sparked my passion for learning Arabic. While her predecessor had strictly followed the lessons in the book, Professor Thomas brought her own materials in the classroom, encouraging us to feel more comfortable speaking. Her liveliness gave me confidence in my ability to learn the language and now, as a Fulbright ETA I continue!

Prof. Thomas is a sweetheart! Classes are a bit disorganized and don't really follow the syllabus though. It's clear she's under pressure by the Arabic Dept to teach specific things, but I found the lessons she created herself to be more helpful to my understanding of the language. Lots of quizzes but her expectations are always reasonable

prof Basu is my favorite professor ever. She is extremely smart, hilarious, super understanding. She facilitates class discussions very well. She shares personal experiences and makes sure every student is heard. Take her class if you have a chance!!!

Prof. Basu's a gem. I took Race and Policy with her (a lot of race and very little policy). The class material was engaging and there was class discussions every day. She uses these mini quizzes that were due for every class day and 2 essays to grade in addition to participation. shes extremely understanding!

Prof. Basu is a solid choice for a Philosophy GE. Reading about Kant, Confusion philosophy, Aristotle was a bit tedious, though, she did make it as interesting as possible. In the second half of the semester, the class became fascinating, though. When working on papers, go speak to her regularly in office hours -- it will really boost your grade.
Professor Basu is creates a really casual atmosphere and does a good job moderating discussions. She's also probably one of the funniest professors I have ever had.

Great professor, super helpful outside of (and inside of) class, and very clear grader who assigns a manageable workload. If you are interested in her area of expertise (which is very relevant to a lot of present social issues), I would highly recommend taking her class.

Professor Basu is one of my favorite professors at CMC! She has a great, casual discussion-oriented structure to her classes and gives out pre-made handouts for you to follow along with in every class. She will always try and relate material to pop-culture and make references that everyone can easily engage with. You won't regret taking her class!

Prof. Favretto's class is so interesting and engaging. She teaches with full knowledge and usually connects her topics to current events. I loved attending her classes because it was so straightforward and interesting. She is also an easy grader and grades based on participation (you can just go to office hours instead), 2 tests and a final paper.

I really enjoyed Professor Favretto's class. It was not very difficult but the content was interesting. The class was lecture-heavy and your grade depends on only two tests and one paper. An A is definitely attainable.

Professor Taylor truly cares about his students. He made himself readily available outside of class to answer any questions and was very helpful in these sessions. The course is very reading heavy, and using the SmartBook function on MH Connect is key to learn the the material. The exams and quizzes were straightforward for the most part.

This prof is a bit scary when you are first getting to know him; he calls on people at random and gets frustrated when you don't understand. BUT he is also very kind, and genuinely wants us to succeed. You learn most of the concepts from the textbook and then go over the problems and exercises in class so don't skip your reading! AlwaysBe prepared.

He should not be teaching this intro class. The exams cover too much material, he is poor at explaining concepts, and gets upset at students when they do not understand the material he is poorly putting forward. The second exam covers 250 pages of dense text book.

I took Professor Taylor for both Business Law and Tax, and he is hands down, one of my favorite professors at CMC.  It's not an easy class, and you WILL have to read in order to do well, but Prof. Taylor truly cares about his students inside and outside his classroom.  Show up to class or your grade will suffer, even if you do well on the tests.
This class was awesome.   I thought the subject would be incredibly boring, but this ended up being one of my favorite classes while at CMC.  I would recommend it to everybody.

Doesn't put up with BS or lazy students and teaches like a real law class. Explains the material very well. Tests were pretty hard but doable if you studied well, except for the final, part of which came from the textbook manufacturer and asked ridiculous questions on stuff from chapters he didn't even tell us to read. Great prof overall though

I loved Prof Taylor! A total badass- could kill Jack Bauer in a barfight. He doesn't waste time or tolerate not doing the reading- but he's very helpful in office hours, and I think he's very funny and interesting.

very boring. crabby and insulting when you don't understand something. like to embarrass students in class (but not in a good way). horrible at explaining the material. 1/5 of the class came to lectures cuz he was so bad. might be good for bus law though. one of the other notes said "some disagree, but he's good." almost everyone disagrees, buddy.

an incredibly dull prof and horrible for intro accounting. he writes illegible chicken scratch on the board and glosses over material, assuming students know how to do it. by the 3rd week, attendance was down to less than half. that tells you something about his teaching and the class. he likes to make students feel stupid and he's just a sourpuss.

some people disagree with me but i thought prof taylor was very good. He applied accounting to the real world and got me real interested in it. He involves everyone in the class and this forces you to do the reading and stay on top of your game. he teaches from the book but the book is really good, hes helped me understand it.

taylor may be ok for business law, but he is terrible for intro accounting. his teaching style is picking on individual students and asking them questions in front of the rest of the class. not only is that potentially embarrassing, but it doesn't help the student learn. they are scared to be called on. exams are very hard and the class is painful

Prof Taylor is the best prof CMC has to offer! He is to the point, and will not put up with BS.  He's invited students over for dinner and has made such an impact on my life.  I think the other students who have rated him not as highly have definitely gott

If you are intelligent, have a strong work ethic, and don't mind standing up for yourself then this is one of the better teachers you can have.  Otherwise you will just think this guy is an ass.  I thought he was one of the best profs at CMC, despite the W

Poor teaching skills. Talks about his tax life too much. Talks about irrelavant Wall Street Journal at the beginning of each class. Poor grading method for final project. Overall bad professor who does not care about the student's performance or understanding in class.
definately learned a lot; personally i was intimidated by him, but he seems like a nice guy
Equally impossible to do very bad and very good.
No Comments

This prof is kind and has good intentions. The homework load is pretty manageable aside from the occasional long textbook readings. Class time was stressful because of how much info he would try to cram in, and it felt rushed. Lab was easy and never took long. I learned a lot.

His lectures are so boring and hard to follow, but also he doesn't put any notes on the slides so if you don't have in-class notes you're screwed for the tests. It's basically just an MCAT prep class and Borchert seems neither qualified for or interested in teaching this class. There were times he did not know what he was talking about or was wrong

This class is essentially a Bio MCAT prep course. You cover a ton of material, but not overly in depth. He is kind and helpful. This isn't his choice area and he got stuck teaching it, but he has a respectable goal: he wants you to learn SOMETHING. Exam's are easy. A blessing if you're taking other Keck sci classes w/ incompetent & HARD profs.

Horribly unhelpful throughout lectures, lab, and just about everything else. He doesn't even seem to have a clear grasp of the material he teaches, so don't expect to learn much or get answers whenever you have a question. Tests were easy and straightforward, but it still doesn't help when he teaches you next to nothing and expects you to know it.

Professor Thomas is a very brilliant guy who will challenge you to think hard and defend your views. You will read and write a ton in his classes, but you will also become a better student because of it. Still, I probably wouldn't take his class if you aren't interested in the subject matter. He has high expectations for students, so be prepared.

Pretty good class. Can be abrasive and cocky towards students, but willing to accept your arguments if they are meritorious. Certainly an expert with a good grasp on where class discussions are going and in what ways he should guide. Hard grader relative to other humanities/social sciences, but not unreasonable and will tell you if your idea sucks

I think that professor Thomas has some favorites and I also believe that  he is not clear with what he wants in essays. . I took his Constitutional law class, and we almost never talked about the theories of constitutional interpretation or some fundamental  philosophies. Get ready to be an independent learner if you take him.

I really enjoyed Professor Thomas' Gov20 class this semester. It's a lot of reading but definitely worth it. He's one of the smartest professors I know and always willing to help. I learnt so much throughout the class and would absolutely recommend taking it!

At first I was hesitant to take a class with Professor Thomas because of what past students have said about the difficulty of the class. But I am so glad I have taken it. This class challenged me in ways I have never been before, and I really grew as an analytical writer and an effective arguer. Definitely recommend this class.
amazing prof and class
Demanding, but great prof.
Awesome

The only discussion based class I had freshman year. I didn't take a single note. A LOT OF READING, IMPOSSIBLE TO GET A GOOD GRADE ON THE ESSAYS, yet if you're into the topic, it is the most intellectually stimulating class you'll get. This is the class that I'm learning the most, even though its kicking my ass.

Class was entirely discussion based.  Assigned absurd amounts of reading.  Impossible to get a decent grade on essays - even if you show him your essay beforehand and do everything he tells you to do, you'll get a mediocre grade at best.  Avoid at all costs.
He's amazing!
Great professor. Lectures are well guided and his office hours are extremely useful. Also arranges out of class activities such as movie nights and dinner which is great!

One of the best professors at CMC. The class is definitely not easy (especially the papers), but it's always interesting. Very discussion-oriented during class. For both 90 & 91, we had three 7-10 page papers & a final exam. If you're interested in Con Law, definitely take a Thomas class.
best prof ever
Very animated. Must do the reading. Very picky on essays.

Prof. Flory really cares about his students and will make time to meet with you outside of class and office hours. He's not the most structured professor so be ready for some flexibility with assignments at random points in the semester.

If I could take him for all my Econ courses at CMC I would! His lectures are amazing! He describes everything so incredibly well in class and is always happy to go over it again in office hours if you ask him! Problem sets help you study for the midterms. An overall fun and engaging class! DEFINITELY RECOMMEND!

Amazing guy. Go to office hours and form a solid relationship. He is very nice and will make an effort to ensure your success if he knows you are working hard.  His lectures go over the readings, therefore if you miss a reading here and there it will not be the end of the world. His slides are shared online and are very helpful for exams.

This class was great. Flory is a great teacher and makes you really understand the concepts. The tests are not hard, you just have to go over the problem sets. Flory grades really easy on exams as well, he does not dock off a lot of points for incorrect math. His lectures were very engaging and not as boring/dry as other Econ lectures.

Professor Flory is a great choice for micro. He gives weekly homework sets that are graded on completion, so you don't have to worry about your grade until the tests come around. The tests are mostly a rehash of the homework, so if you go over the problem sets you'll do fine. Quirky sense of humor, would recommend.
Did not let us out on time early, not helpful, only teaches in one way, hard to contact. One of the worst classes

He is a nice guy and teaches things very clear. Lecture slides are updated on sakai weekly. His lecture is slow-paced and easy. If you want to learn a lot then don't pick him but if you like a easy ECON 101, he would be a good choice.
Great guy, really friendly. Makes you work hard and has some busy work, but overall a good course. Would recommend to others

Had no idea what he was doing. Took a really interesting subject matter and made a complete debauchery by assigning unreasonable amount of work that was not even stimulating.  Class was very disorganized. Its sad because he's a good guy and obviously really smart, but unfortunately still hasn't got a hang of teaching undergraduate level courses.

Prof. Petropoulos is very knowledgeable about WWII. Lots of readings and memorization, but it is manageable.

Reason for not taking him again: he can definitely do better in tolerating political views that don't necessarily champion democracy, and he talks often takes up half the class to talk about current global situations.

JP's class was my favorite class I have ever taken. He has an unreal level of experience in his field of Weimar/Nazi Germany. Zoom class with Petropoulos was full of some of the best presentations I've ever seen. He always kept the course interesting, but we wrote 20 pages of papers during the final 2 weeks. I can't wait for my next class with JP

Prof Petropolous is a fantastic professor and is probably too good for CMC -- he is the world expert in his field. He is hard but you will learn and lot! Reading is heavy but there are ways to work around doing all of it. Only take this class if you are willing to do the work, contribute: otherwise, it is probably not the class for you.

I've taken him twice now and loved every minute of it. He's a gem of a man and a professor. He made me change my major to history. His classes are ridiculously hard, make no mistake though. You're often reading 300+ pages a week and he's a hard grader. But it's impossible to hate his class. Also, has an obsession with Harvard.

Johny is a Greek God. He convinced me to take a history dual with my major. He is by far the most helpful prof at CMC if you visit his office hours (He's always available) and will help you with outside-class stuff too.   LOTS of reading though. 200 pages a week for my class. But totally worth it.

Relatively interesting class, 3 papers worth 10% each and a final. While this may sound easy, he is a stickler for the rules. Perfect grammar is necessary to even get a B+ in the class and he is quite stingy when it comes to handing out A's. Do not take this class if you're looking for an easy History GE

Fantastic professor, really wants you to understand the material (note that the material he selects is absolutely excellent too). You will learn a lot and come to appreciate his anecdotes. Well travelled and highly intelligent. Extremely helpful and available. Lots of reading, papers and tests graded harshly (he has high standards for his students)

Best professor at CMC! His FHS is the reason why I and many of my friends decided to major in history. German history is incredibly fascinating and important! Nicest guy with plenty of coy jokes and ridiculous stories.

Petropoulos is a fantastic professor and is extremely well versed in German history.  His lectures are extremely engaging, and he really works to make you excited about the material.  Expect to read a TON in his class (~300p/wk).  Papers are graded very fairly, tests very harshly.  As a result, I recommend taking him for a seminar class!

Professor Petropoulos was my favorite teacher freshman year.  His FHS class is absolutely amazing.  The workload is high, but manageable, and the readings are engaging.  His a really interesting person and a phenomenal teacher.  You won't regret taking a class from him.
Has a lot of academic integrity and is very easy to relate to interpersonally. Overall a very significant asset to the college.

A great professor, really cares about his students and the material he is teaching. A lot of reading, but if you work hard you will ultimately be rewarded (both with a good grade and learning a lot). Definitely recommend taking a class with him - his specialty is World War II/the Holocaust so I recommend taking that class with him.

Great professor, really engaging. He is very passionate and knowledgeable on the subject matter - this class was called "Researching the Holocaust" and I learned a lot. He is also very accommodating in terms of the workload, although he assigns a lot of reading. I would definitely recommend him though.
Great professor. I've had him twice and he is amazing. Expects a lot of his students, a lot of assigned readings (average a book a week) and several papers. Really fun in class.
Amazing professor, very engaging. I would highly recommend this prof, but be prepared to work your ass off.
Took a seminar class from him.  Very into the structure of writing.  Assigns very high level readings.  Invited class to his house for dinner. Talks about himself a lot, but it's mostly relevant.

I am in love with this man! He's full of hilarious anecdotes (if you get him on a tangent, he'll go on and on...in a good way) and truly loves his work.  This class was intense, but my favorite of the semester and the discussion was interesting.  There are only several papers (7-8 pages) and a research paper (10-15 pages) at the end of the year.
An amazing professor with a real passion for the subject. Very funny and innovative in teaching techniques. WWI "helmet day" rocked!
Very Interesting teacher. Knows a lot of the "interesting" facts about history especially Nazi's and WW's.  A ton of reading but some of it you can get around, not a lot though. Good Lectures.

I'm honestly amazed at how well-produced his lecture videos are. They are clear, informative, and include plenty of examples. He definitely makes you work for your grade-3 exams, 2 papers, and 20 or so homework quizzes, but by the end, you will have a strong grasp of managerial accounting.

Econ86 is a must take if you go to CMC. Ganguly teaches in a flipped classroom style, which is different from the other accounting professors, but I found it to be the most useful way to learn all the content in accounting because there is a lottttt to learn. He has very high expectations, but that is because he cares about his students succeeding.
Very challenging for an intro class. Overcomplicates things that could be taught in easier ways. Expect to spend 10+ hours a week watching videos, doing HW quizzes and reviewing.

Took Econ 86 in my Soph year. (I just graduated.) You figure out how good Ganguly is AFTER his class. You leave other Econ86 sections smoking in the dust at interviews and in higher accounting and finance courses. Everything they teach you, you already have a pretty good start on. Very thorough, very dedicated, guy. You get what you put in.

Ganguly's class was by far the most time consuming course I have taken. You learn a lot but it is pretty much all on your own time. Friendly guy, but I would not take this class again if given a second chance.

Youll struggle if youve never taken accounting! You HAVE TO review EVERYTHING or fall behind! Ganguly is an amazing prof though, willing to help, cares for his students, very passionate about acctg which is nice. his class covers more than massoud's. super doable to get an A but u have to dedicate time. participation matters, prepare to learn!

It's impossible to describe Ganguly. His videos are helpful and its great that you can go back to watch them, but this class is just so much work (really, if you want to do well, you will will easily be doing 12+ hours a week). He will seem pretty tough at times-don't take it personally. Enjoy his little catchphrases, and learn lots of accounting.

The best Flipped Classroom format on campus. I asked for his videos even when preparing for a later class. For the record, he was not late even once in posting videos ... not in Spring 2018... so those other complaints of late postings must be from earlier when he was making all the videos while teaching the class at the same time.

I wish I had taken this class earlier! It is by far the most applicable class I have taken in college and Professor Ganguly is an amazing prof. Hes tough, the class is A TON of work but you leave really knowing your stuff!

This was one of the most condescending teachers I have ever had. His class is at best hard to follow and poorly organized. He also blatantly lied about how he creates tests saying he wouldn't use the textbook for specific questions, however, in office hours, he told me that he created several questions in direct reference to the textbook.

Flipped classroom was PHENOMENAL!  Much better than I imagined.  Yes, it was a bit annoying that videos were often posted late this first time around, but each time he invited students to request extra time if they needed it.  I asked for extension several times, and got no issues.  So did my friends.  So, he made accommodations for the lateness.

Professor Ganguly tried a flipped classroom with us for the first time, so he was super late getting the videos to us (would put them out at like 8 or 9 pm the night before they were due the next day by noon), yet held us to strict deadlines which was very frustrating. That shouldn't be a problem in the future, however as the videos are made now.

This prof is quite the badass: extremely clear, friendly, and energetic. Class is much more interesting than the typical Econ class, and flipped classroom was much better than you'd think. His tests are brutally straightforward if you study - no surprises (some of the questions were much, much easier than what you do in class). Recommend  100%

You don't have much choice for professors if you have to take this class, and there are very few people who take this subject for fun. The class is hard but if you really apply yourself you should be fine. The flipped classroom helps a lot because it makes you study the material over and over again. Study hard for the midterms, they're brutal.
Enjoyed the class very much.  Not sure what this "ferocious" stuff is.  Last semester his class of 30ish had like 10 As and 15 Bs if I remember right.  If you want easier classes go be a Psych major.

This class was one of the most difficult classes, but also made me decide to become and Econ/Accounting major. This class is very very fast paced, so make sure to pay attention.  You will learn A LOT abut accounting, this is the sort of class where you will get out as much as you put in.  Would not recommend as an elective!!

Really loves accounting. Can be helpful in office hours. Big on group projects and problem sets. Make a lot of errors during lectures. Tries to be very personable. Tries to trick you a bit on the tests.
Crazy expectations for a introductory accounting class. Super difficult concepts that are not clearly defined. Very wordy and hard to follow correspondence, class notes and lectures.

Complicates accounting to the highest degree. Think it was impossible to be assigned a paper and be critiqued on writing ability in an accounting class? Think again.  He's terribly confusing in class and easily has one of the largest egos of any professor at CMC. Do not, absolutely DO NOT take him. It's not easier nor better than Massoud's class
I don't think I would've liked accounting/decided to be an Econ-Accounting major if it weren't for professor Ganguly. He's funny and extremely helpful both inside and outside of the classroom

Very useful class.  If you're into starting your small business, you will love it.  Concepts are hard, the textbook is way too unnecessarily hard to follow, but becomes clearer if you follow class. Don't take it in your last semester, because the last week gets hectic.  My one complaint is that he could be more accomodating of graduating seniors.
Great professor.  Turned me into an econ-accounting major.  This is a course you will work hard for, and the exams are tough, but the overall grading ends up being half the class A's and B's.

Ganguly is a nice guy. He is articulate, loud, constantly repeating himself. However, I cannot begin to tell you how ridiculous this class is. Impossible for an intro class. Expects way way too much from everyone. Tests are ferociously hard and the term project will have you running in circles. NOT an intro professor. Intelligent at highest level.

Pay attention in class when he goes through the cases and will do well. 1 paper, a midterm, a final, and two case presentations. Doesn't grade very difficultly as long as put in the work and study well for exams
I would only take this class if you are having an affair with Scalia's ghost.

Teaches only through lecturing and doesnt engage with students. Often has anecdotes that can be somewhat entertaining but arent useful in terms of the tests or material. Not as easy of a class as his reputation on campus suggests.

A true legend and scholar. Not graded on many things but criteria is vert clear and if you put in the work an A should be achievable. Very lecture heavy, class can sometimes get tedious but he is a super knowledgable guy. If you are into gov and do the readings you will get a lot out of the class, if you are not it is feasible to flourish.

A truly wonderful man. Does not assign any homework, your grade consists of a midterm, final paper, and final test. He will stand up and speak for the entire time but you only need to take notes when you directly ask what is on the test a few days before. Tests are not difficult. Enjoy the class
He's definitely very right wing in his politics. Needs to be more impartial fair and balanced. I felt it was manipulative.

Prof Rossum is probably my favorite prof so far.  He is clear, intelligent, and experienced.  Intro to Law has been an amazing experience, there has been a ton of reading.  At one point, I had two days to read a 350 page book, so get ready to hunker down.  Also, he makes his right-wing political views quite apparent, especially when not asked.

Definitely one of the smartest and most well known (especially in the law community) professors at CMC. Genuinely nice guy, and is much better in office hours. Can't match the connections he has, and his interesting tales about teaching with Scalia

While Rossum's lectures can be a bit dry, he really knows his stuff, and he'll try to make it interesting as often as possible.  His passion for the subject (the American Founding) was evident, and made the subject much more enjoyable.  Assignments are minimal.  He grades fairly, and is lax on due dates.  Overall, one of my favorite profs at CMC.
No Comments
No Comments

While he was a good prof. and the class was worthwhile, I was a little bothered by the way he made his political views abundantly clear. His love of Scalia and the Right made the class less about education and more about indoctrination. He sometimes couldn't tell us the other point of view, which shouldn't be the case.

Rossum is a great lecturer and you know the Supreme Court cases well but there isnt much discussion.  Also, he is a bit hard of a grader and takes seemingly random points on midterms, but the quality of work and reading is not too demanding.

Smart, smart guy. "Fair" grader. I probably would have learned a lot more in his class if I did any of the reading, but it was still really interesting. Boring lectures, but once in a while he'll slip in a joke that is hilarious if you can catch it -- most people don't.
My favorite professor ever. Maybe because the material was very interesting, and maybe because he graded me easily.  Just do the reading, and you'll be fine even if you go to class once a month.
Original thinker, only down side is that he doesn't do enough of the teaching himself.
His views are a little out there, but the material is pretty interesting and he's a nice guy overall.

One of my favorite classes and professors at CMC. It's helpful to take Statistics or Metrics before enrolling in this class, but Professor Bjerk does a great job explaining the material clearly and thoroughly. I loved how we learned through relevant Economic papers. Everything felt very applicable.

I LOVED Prof Bjerk. An econ class that really made you think with a professor who took think the time to answer everyone's question. Sometimes he cold called, but as long as you did the reading, it wasn't a problem. Really learned a lot, and Bjerk came at things very objectively but still with a great passion.
Bjerk is super chill, makes things clear and is a pretty easy grader. I'd recommend him to anyone,
He does a great job setting the groundwork for microeconomics.
I have taken more than one classes with him. Definitely my favorite professor ever.  He's clear, organized, helpful. Right amount of workload and all exam questions are very reasonable.

Bjerk is incredible. He's very down to earth, easy to talk with, and a fair grader - the kind of professor who made me WANT to work really hard. The discussions we had as a class were intriguing and made the concepts and theory seem very relevant. Homework is quite manageable. I would highly recommend going to the weekly homework help sessions.

Awesome Professor. A must take. Not too much homework. The homework is important and is meant to help you. Tests test how well you comprehend the info in different situations. They will make you think. Not too much homework. Once a week. Woud take again!

Bjerk makes micro as interesting as a micro class can be (which imo is not the most exciting subject). He is super clear, his slides are very understandable, you do not need to read the book, let alone buy it, and the workload is light. His tests can be tricky and conceptual, but people have gotten 100% on them too.

I just loved his class. One of the BEST classes that I took at CMC. He is a great lecturer. Simply by showing up to the class and sitting there, you can learn a lot. (Of course you need to work to get an A) His tests are pretty straight forward, and he lets you bring a cheat sheet. I'm definitely going to take this class again!

Micro with him was pretty straightforward (and dare I say easy). His exam questions were very conceptual and thus not bad at all if you grasp the concepts. As a bonus he's cute so you feel slightly more motivated to drag yourself to lecture at 8AM...

While the pace of the class was quick, I began to appreciate Bjerk more and more throughout the semester. He is clear, nice, and engaging. When he strays away from the theory and computations and discusses practical stuff, the class becomes extremely interesting. The tests are hard to ace, but are fair and completely feasible. Take him for 101!

Professor Bjerk is extremely attentive, interested, and enthusiastic. He grades pretty difficultly and doesn't follow the textbook much at all, leaving lectures as the primary source for information, so you have to pay attention. Also, lecture slides are left blank so you have to attend class.

Professor Bjerk is probably one of the best professors I've had at CMC. I went into this class knowing NOTHING about econ (I didn't learn anything in econ 50), but Bjerk taught concepts from the basics. He's clear and effective. If you do the weekly homework (4ish easy problems), online readings, and actually study for midterms, you can get an A.

Professor Bjerk is a nice guy. Always teaches with Powerpoint slides. There is a lot of information, so don't plan on missing class. You have weekly homework problem sets graded on completion, 2 midterms and one cum. final. The tests are fair, but a bit tricky. Be prepared to study hard before tests.

A very organized professor who makes himself available for his students. Problem sets help you understand the material. Although, the book is not as useful, if you listen in class and do the homework, you will do well.

Micro: His lectures are clear and he is very helpful during office hours. I would strongly recommend using a different texbook than the one he uses though(Varian), as it lacks examples and is very bland. He's not good at giving partial credit during exams, which definately bothered many students. Overall, I really enjoyed the class!

This is a decent class. The issue is the lack of practice students get with the material. If you are good at math, this class is simple. If you are okay at math, this class is decent. Textbook is terrible and if you want practice with the material, it would help to just buy a good textbook. The concepts are tough and he is generally theory-based

Professor Day is a funny guy who cares about his students. The class material is really straight forward, but you won't do well on the quizzes and papers if you don't do the readings or show up to class.
A good professor. As long as you study hard, you will get the grade you deserved. A pretty straight forward class in my opinion.

Professor Finley did a great job converting his ECON086 class into the virtual pandemic environment. His course is the most organized virtual course at CMC I've seen, and he is very accessible to help students. If you put in the time and effort, he will work with you.

Yes, Finley is boring, but he is also very consistent and does not throw curveballs on exams. If you pay attention in class you will do well because exams are similar to class. He offers plenty of practice problems. He cares about his students learning accounting and effort. He did not make the class any easier during the pandemic which felt unfair

Really great professor! The lectures are super clear. He provides an outline of the lecture that you can print out and write notes in. It's mostly example-based, which I really found useful. The exams are comprehensive so be ready to apply multiple tax rules to one case. The homework and cases are fair and don't take too much time.
Extremely difficult, unhelpful. Guy is a total robot and an awful teacher. Lectures are guided, fill in the blanks, however he tests on conceptual things that aren't covered in the lectures. Sucks

Finley has changed his curriculum to make his class a lot better. He provides notes for the class to print out that make everything really clear and easy to review. A bit dry, but he gets the job done and has a subtle sense of awkward humor.

A very organized Professor who really knows his stuff. He makes handouts for every single chapter that make it really clear what he will be testing you on. He is also really good about providing assistance outside of class if you need it. If you put in the work, you'll get the grade you want.

Definitely take Finley for Tax Planning. He was once a Tax Professional, so this is his area of expertise, and he truly displays it. His handouts in class very clearly outline what we need to know, and he has an organized style of teaching. He had super helpful office hours and he is really willing to help students who reach out. Highly recommend!

He's still a new prof. Could definitely spice up his teaching style. Cannot tell what is or isn't important based on lectures. I feel like if I went to more office hours I would've had a better idea of what he expected.

1) HE IS THE WORST! LITERALLY.  2) DO NOT TAKE HIM IF YOU WANT TO PURSUE AN ECON/ACCOUNTING DEGREE. 3) HE READS OFF THE SLIDES AND EXPLAINS NOTHING 4) HIS HOMEWORKS ARE ONLINE AND ARE 100 TIMES HARDER THAN WHAT HE TEACHES IN CLASS 5) HE WONT CURVE THE CLASS EVEN IF AVERAGE GRADE IS A FAIL 6) TOO HARD FOR AN INTRO CLASS 7) RUINS GPA

Fucaloro explains concepts somewhat pretty clearly and there's times where he'll go on a tangent, but overall, a great prof. The exams were extremely easy, and you don't need to even read the textbook. He tells you exactly what's on the exam. If you show up to class and pay attention, it's an easy A.

Fuc is funny and getting an A in pchem was easy - just two open note exams. That's it. And you're allowed to ask questions on them. However, it was grueling because I didn't learn single thing and all you rely on is notes. He doesn't really teach- just writes his notes on the board in barely legible handwriting and his office hours are his phone #

Fuc is very lecture heavy, which worked pretty well for me, but it's not for everyone. He's not very accessible (no office hours) but he does give you his phone number, and I've talked to him after class a few times and he's always been nice. Wouldn't say he's the best prof but he's not horrible. Also, he gives you last year's test as a study guide

The midterms and final for this class are so easy. He literally gives you a "study guide" that will look very very very similar to the test so take it very seriously and try to learn exactly what's on it. Do the homework because it counts for credit. Study his handouts because they are very useful and essential for passing tests.
Hands down the worst prof I've had at CMC. Great teacher if you're a chem genius, if not you're out of luck. Is aggressively unhelpful and ridicules those who ask for clarification or extra help.
If you pay attention in class and ask questions when you're unclear, you'll do fine. He tests directly from his notes.
Love this guy. Literally you just need to copy the notes from the board into your notebook and you will be prepared for the exams.

Boring lectures. He makes fun of people and answers questions with rhetorical questions. Although you may hate him, you will realize when you get a different professor how good Fucaloro was actually. His tests are very straight forward
no help at all. makes fun of people who ask questions.
Terrible at explaining. Notes are disorganized and lectures hard to follow. Completely self taught by the book. Not recommended.

Booooooo.  I did not like Fuculoro at all.  I could actually rant about this.  He might as well have openly told us that he didn't care about us learning at all.  Yes, it is easy...so take it if that is all you want. But if you want to actually learn, your wasting your time is his class.

Best Chemistry teacher i have ever had.  He is amazing and hysterical.  He tells you exactly what will be on the test  wants you to do well.  He sneaks funny side comments in what make the class entertaining.  HIGHLY RECOMMEND
What can I say, the man is a legend. He answers his cell phone in class, that's how dedicated he is to his students. A true modern renaissance man with an old Italian charm.

I took Fuc second semester and it was not only much more interesting than Zanella's class, but much easier. He gives you templates for exactly how to solve problems - unless you're a lazy ass - you should be acing his tests. Doesn't take attendance, but if you don't go, youll miss the answers. Honestly, didn't pick up my text book more than 5 times

Fucaloro may be good at chemistry, but he is the worst seminar leader. His class was mostly just him rambling about his own opinions and going off into random complicated chemistry problems. Not really an FHS class at all. On the plus side, he's hilarious and the class was super easy, you almost didn't even have to come and there's no homework.

really easy...u'll be dissapointed if you don't get him for chem14.  take him at all costs to ur schedule.  just understand material and u'll get an A, he'll basically give you the tests the day b4 class

Fucaloro is AMAZING!! If you have the opportunity to have him as a teacher take it. He teaches you what you need to know not all the other unnecessary material. Short and to the point!!! I wish I had him for Chem 015 as well.

Easiest class I've had. Great lectures! The hw was a bit hard, but the take home tests weren't bad at all. Just write down what he says in lecture word for word. If the tests had been in-class... this would have been difficult but as it was...easy.
Good teacher, fair tests that are very straightforward. I took Purvis-Roberts first and he was amazing after her! I would highly reccomend his class, it is very math based.

Great guy.  By his own admission he teaches to the tests.  He is very organized and very easy to understand.  He will teach you everything you need to know.  I understood his class much better than my chem 14 with williams, but I like williams better than fuc.  Fuc is funny, but if you don't understand he is not very willing to help you, but its ez
Easy tests, very sarcastic and entertaining, makes fun of students, fair grader
Love this subject but this guy has no idea to teach to anyone who has a different learning style.  If you only need one explanation then you are fine but your screwed if you need another exlanation.
All in all, a great teacher!
Genuinely intelligent and helpful.  All lectures are very clear and the tests are fair.  Has a fun sense of humor too.
These catagories don't fully express the wonder and delight of his class periods.  He is basically a master of the subject.  He lectures on everything he tests on.

I would really recommend taking a course with Prof. Espinosa if you are very interested in the course content - there's a lot of reading and writing. But, he is extremely knowledgable and a super interesting guy, so if you are willing to put in the work, you should not encounter any problems. He does take a while with grading, which can be rough.

Not a hard class, but all of the work is terrible. Each essay is dictated sentence by sentence what you need to write and it's just a cookie cutter response to a lot of really shallow, mostly plot based questions that oftentimes don't even feel relevant to the movies. It just takes a long time and is rote work. Online class was also a trainwreck.

Professor Espinosa is truly passionate about studying religion, which makes for interesting class discussions. The readings can be lengthy, but they are usually very interesting. Every other week you have to write a one-page summary/analysis of a particular reading. He is accessible outside of class, very caring, and tends to talk a lot.

He's kinda out there -- goes on lots of tangents, repeats himself a lot, a bit disorganized -- but is clearly very passionate about the subject and keeps things interesting for the most part. Approachable and accessible outside of class. Participation is definitely required

Prof Espinosa is great, but he LOVES to talk (about himself). Ask him 1 question and his response will be an hour long (I timed this). He also expects A LOT from his students. The amount of reading and writing u have to do is almost inhumane. That being said, he also cares a lot, and his classes r very interesting and fun if u r willing 2 work hard

Prof Espinosa has high expectations from his students. Do not recommend taking him for a GE because it's a crapton of work. Class was 6-10 pm on Thursdays sometimes running over because he cannot keep time properly. He is disorganized and does not give back papers in a timely manner. That being said, his class is one of the more interesting ones.

Professor Espinosa is a prof you take for a class you are truly passionate about. Taken as a GE, it can be a crapton of work and unless you go to his office hours you never seem to know what he wants out of a paper. His Religion & Film class was cool as it encompassed film techniques too but was 4 hours long on Thursday nights! Get ready to write

Professor Espinosa's class was easy enough but extremely boring. He talks a lot, it was all lecture and I would not recommend it. There are also papers due every two weeks that just felt like busy work.

Very great person (empathetic and willing to compromise). One of the most caring professors I have. As for class, it can get boring since you just discuss what you read but usually he is the one who does all the talking. Many readings assigned although many are interesting. Only write a paper every other week. Try not take advantage of his kindnes

Professor Espinosa's RPGV class was by far the best class I've taken at the 5C's. It's a ton of work, but the content and books assigned are absolutely fascinating. It actually made me almost become a Religious Studies major. Sadly, he's on sabbatical this year, but I can't wait for him to come back so I can take more of his courses!

Expect tons (200+ pages a week) of reading, very unclear grading, and inspirational-ish tangents. Content-based reading questions due every other week, threatens pop quizzes but never gives them. Asks you to buy tons of books, but you don't read all of them (especially if you only read every other week and fake it the off weeks)

Professor Espinosa is obviously intelligent but it he doesn't take the time to prep for his classes. We go over the same things- he shows the same videos, we have a poorly set up debate every class and we go over same questions. 300+ pages of reading weekly, bi-weekly 2 pg. papers (get same grade every time- 88). Flakes on office hours.

Great readings - do them on your own. Awful teacher. Pointless essays answering 10 to 20 specific, content-oriented, non-analytical questions on the reading. Class spent answering questions that you JUST did for your essay. Changingambivalent final paper expectations. Pretentious professor. No true academic dialogue - you're expected to conform.

Prof. Espinosa is very knowledgable and sophisticated. He assignes more readings and papers than average, but he also gives very detailed feedbacks. He corrects all the papers very thoroughly and I feel like I come out of this class a better writer. He is a tough grader, rarely gives out A or A-, mostly B+.

He is the worst teacher ever. He only accepts his own opinion and allows for no discussion in class he doesn't agree with.  He assigns 50 page readings and requires you to print out all of them, better stock up on ink and paper! All his class focuses on is Calvinism because he likes it. If you have him for FHs switch out.

I can't stop taking his classes. Readings are engaging, relevant, and the subject matter is controversial as ever, what an exciting course! RPV is the best class I took in college and opened my eyes in ways never thought imaginable. Very committed to building his dept and making sure his students come away having learned more. Take his class!!

Took Religion, Politics, and Global Violence and he almost converted me to a Religious Studies major. I LOVED the class. With reaction papers, readings, and essays it's a ton of work but seminars are held in his house and you learn more than almost any other class. He's willing to help in any way possible, fun field trips and speakers!

Religion, Politics, and Global Violence was hands down my favorite class of my senior year. Prof. Espinosa did an amazing job of selecting the readings, I found them very interesting and valuable to my understanding of the topic. He was always available outside of class and very helpful on papers and other projects. I definitely recommend the class

Profesor Espinosa is an incredibly dedicated professor both to his students as well as to his work in academia. Although work load is heavy, it is necessary to really dig into the subject matter to leave class with an understanding of the topics we address. Professors like Espinosa are the perks of going to a small college like CMC.

I took his Race: A History class and I love the topic and some readings, but discussions were literally regurgitating what the author said in the reading, which was extremely frustrating. but he is a smart & thoughtful guy when you talk to him during office hours. great personality, but i disagree wit his teaching methods. (talks too much too)

The religion and film class is so fun! I mean we analyzed star wars, lord of the rings, the matrix and indiana jones from a religious perspective! He is SO interesting and helpful - if you give him a rough draft of every essay you write, he will edit it for you and if you follow his exact edited instructions, that paper is a guaranteed A.

Religion, Politics and Global Violence: I LOVE prof espinosa and his teaching style. He really knows his stuff, is so enthusiastic about it, and is SO helpful outside of class. He has a sign up sheet for individual office hours and meals every week! I'm normally a slacker when it comes to work, but even with the heavy reading and lots of writing fo
He is the kind of professor you either love or hate. He is a really nice guy and means well, however his class and teaching methods drove me crazy.

One of my all-time favorite professors, he is encouraging to every student with whom I have EVER seen him interact.  Will work with students tirelessly to help learning, this professor is an excellent resource and a true teacher.  He's great at converting students to RS majors and is concentrating on building up this program at the colleges.

I want to express my gratitude for the course on the History of World Christianity. I continue to be shocked by just how much I remember and how what I've learned continues to inform my life. This was one of the best courses I took in college.

Do not take his class! Absurd amounts of work and readings.  Tests are impossible. Early Saturday morning field trips.  Doesn't care about his students, completely unhelpful. ARROGANT!! Brags about himself and what he's done at every available opportunity. Any redeeming quality is offset by his smug attitude and the magnitude of work required.

The worst Prof I have ever taken. Gives way to much work that does not seem to help in learning. Required (no make ups!) three field trips on sundays at 8am! Does not listen to any student comments and does not return any work submitted. I have yet to get back a paper I turned in in September. DO NOT take any class by him.

This man is the hardest and best professor I've had so far.  He will make you work more than you've ever worked before, but he makes it worth your while and fascinating. As long as you're not scared of shouldering a burden and getting the most of your college education, take a class with him, it's worth it.

He may have killed my interest in religion and politics. He gives a lot of hard busy work that is extremely unhelpful toward increasing our understanding. He doesn't listen to student comments--instead he seems to be always waiting for a chance to show off or say something good about himself.
one of the worst classes I've had. A smug, arrogant person with little concern for students.
Professor Reed was amazing. Class had a lot of lectures but the discussions were relaxed and fun. A couple reports and some quizzes here and there.
Reed assigned a lot of readings and worksheets. Tests were okay but too lengthy. Overall a very caring professor. She also gave out a lot of tips about college and life in general.

Prof. Reed cares a lot about her students and is very passionate about the material. The lectures are pretty boring but as long as you put in the work, you will do well. This class is a lot of memorization and a lot of homework that isn't necessarily difficult but just takes a long time. She is very accessible out of class and helpful.

The class is really lecture heavy but she makes the material really engaging (ipsi & contra dance). She is really accommodating over zoom with the test window over multiple days. The class is mostly just reading through research articles and 3 exams.

Good class. Prof. Reed's lectures can be boring but she is very enthusiastic about the material. Take it if you are genuinely interested in memorizing brain parts and their functions. Lots of group work and you read a lot of research. Prof. Reed is a bit moody at times.

Although lectures can be dry, Professor Reed clearly cares about her students, and takes time out of her own day to make sure everyone gets feedbacks on the tests. Her exams are demanding but as long as you put in the time to study you'll be fine. There's also a large final paper but she outlines it well and it's easier to complete than it looks.

Her classes are structured really well for the entire semester: 2 midterms and 1 final (which was another midterm). It's important to listen in her lectures and do the reading to understand for the next class. She really cares for her students and is very proficient at teaching.

I love Dr. Reed! Once I got the hang of the class, I really enjoyed her teaching and the material. I went to her office hours multiple times-- she gave me good ideas for my final paper and even let me redo a test question I had missed.  She organized a fun class dinner and really tried to get to know us.  Definitely recommend this class!!
Warning: this will be the most boring class you will ever take. Avoid at all cost. Prof Reed is not good at teaching, and she goes off topic all the time during lecture.

Cathy smothered the ever existing interest I had in psychology after taking her intro to psyc. Don't get me wrong - she is super nice and cares a lot about her students, but her lectures are too dry. Some people say she is easy - not necessarily. I find her midterm questions confusing.

She is very condescending during office hours and unnecessarily blunt. She does not know how to encourage students to do better on assignments as she treats them like they are dumb or lost causes. She also has no filter and discusses your academics in front of other students. She also gets flustered before she's even asked you if you understand!

It's true, she did speak in a way that insults students' intelligence, which made class very boring. Some assignments seemed like busy-work, and she does read off of her slides for "lecture". Her perkiness was also very annoying. However, the class isn't really too hard. Test questions are usually worded the exact same way her slides are.

If you're looking to get an easy A GE out of the way, intro psych with reed is the way to go. The class is really easy, but she is an awful teacher that teaches down the material so much so that going to her class is an annoyance. She means well, but her class is a glorified daycare full of powerpoint heavy lecture and condescendingly slow pacing.

She is incredibly boring.  Professor Reed is obviously interested in the material but she just lacks the ability to teach.  Way too powerpoint heavy, I find myself copying down her powerpoints verbatim.  Her tests aren't too hard, but beware that she is awful at teaching the material.
Professor Reed is very passionate about what she teaches. She makes the class fun and interactive. There is no final (it's only a midterm). Material is very interesting and easy to understand.

Prof reed is good- but very powerpoint heavy and sometimes it felt like she was teaching middle schoolers b/c the material was dumbed-down. That said, it would be a good psych GE and if you have any deeper interest prof Reed is really eager to get students into lab.
Professor Reed is very nice and a lot of fun. She uses a lot of powerpoint. Also, very upfront about expectations for papers and exams. As long as you put in a basic amount of work, you'll do fine.

She was an easy teacher although we had to write up things every week in the class. She is so enthusiastic it is infectious, and really helps make the class much more enjoyable, especially when she went into topics that I didn't find interesting at all.

Uses lots of PowerPoints in class. The book is never used in class, but read it. It helps for the test and papers. The final isn't cumulative, which is great. Tests are pretty easy if you don't just cram the night before.
Awesome professor.  She helps make the material straightforward.  Really cool person, so she can help with any problem you're having in the class.  Good for GE and major.

Prof Sinclair is super sweet and understanding - he made an assignment optional when everyone was stressing out about midterms. He gives pretty good feedback and always has something interesting to say. Definitely would take a class with him again!

Prof. SInclair truly knows his field and tried his best to make quite a dull compulsory course (GOV020) as interesting as possible. He is heavy on papers (1x12 page, 2x6 page, 1x4 page) than exams (1xbig final, no midterms). His prompts were not the easiest to understand and he tends to reply to emails with one-word answers which wasn't helpful.
Professor Sinclair is the man. Very helpful, funny, and clear. Can not recommend one of his classes enough if you want to get inspired about politics and public policy.
Super helpful, and super nice. Very clear in lecture and very helpful when writing papers.

Madison's macro class is difficult, but rewarding. For those less comfortable with derivatives it may not be a good choice, as it is math heavy. He's very accessible and willing to meet often to help students. He truly does care about his students and wants to help them improve and understand.

Professor Madison is the best Economics professor I've had at CMC. Don't get me wrong, you'll have to put in work to do well because the class material is very difficult, but Professor Madison explains everything step by step in a very thorough and easy to follow manner. He's always willing to answer questions during and outside of class as well.

Prof. Ozbekilk is super nice and a good teacher. His online classes are mainly lectures, but he tries to get the class involved by asking us questions and playing games. I would recommend going to office hours to talk to him so he knows you + you get extra help! Fairly straightforward class. Quiz every week, midterm, test, homework.

Although he is unquestionably a nice man, I deeply do not recommend Ozbeklik. His classes don't adequately prepare you for your midterm and final (which are worth 60%), and his lectures are the most painful I have ever sat through. His grading is wildly arbitrary for written exams. If you have the option, take Econ50 with a different professor.

Prof Ozbeklik was Ok but the lectures weren't really interesting. I could not pay attention during lectures, so I ended up skipping lectures and watching them later at 2.0 speed. Homework tests and quizzes are reasonable

Prof Ozbeklik is really nice and tries hard to make the class engaging. I personally hate econ, and doing this online was tough. He just lectures during class, put he posts the recordings and the slides so I can go back and take good notes later. Quizzes every week and easy, straightforward assignments. One of my few profs who sticks to syllabus!

Super engaging lectures & not that much homework (homework is a bit difficult but tutoring and office hours makes it very manageable). The exams are HARD, the lectures are mostly general concepts and the exams are mostly calculation and applications. Many people failed & got C's on the first midterm, but extra credit report will help overall grade

Let me start by saying that econ and I don't get along. But if I had to suffer through econ for a GE requirement, I'm glad to have done it with Mr. Ozbeklik. He is such a sweetheart and will work you through any problem. He gives out the answers for quizzes and assignments AND he's not bad to look at... at all. Great teacher, terrible subject.

It was my first time taking Econ and Ozbeklik made it a fun experience. The tutoring hours helps so so much. No need to read the textbook because his lecture presentations are straight from the textbook and clear enough. Do all that he says while preparing for the midterms and you will be alright. If you don't his midterms are going to seem so hard

Go to office hours if you are confused at all, but the textbook and website do a good job of making it clear.  Great into class that made me change my major.  Very nice guy who wants you to do well if you show that you care.

Class is lecture style with power points, but gives students power points beforehand so class can be kind of boring. No surprises on tests if you go through past quiz questions and practice questions. Straight forward class, but not the most invigorating professor.

Although he is nice, I found his exams to be much more complicated than his lectures and homework even after a lot of studying. There are a lot of trick questions and you basically work down to the very last minute. Having said that, this is a relaxing class with not that much work, but once again the hard tests really limit how well you do.

An average professor. Midterms and finals are much harder than the book, and his lectures do not adequately prepare you for them. There is also a prevalent language barrier that makes him hard to understand. However, his grading isn't terrible. Don't expect to get a perfect A, but don't think you're in a world of hurt either if you end up with him.
The class is not bad work wise, but Ozbeklik can be unclear at times and grading on tests is very arbitrary.
It was his first time teaching the class, and he definitely tried to make it as good as possible. He was accommodating and nice, the class is just incredibly hard.
he was awesome. i came into his class thinking econ was not my thing but he made the material interesting for me. he's extremely patient so do not hesitate to go in for help, it helped me a lot.

He used powerpoints straight from the book's material, but explained things very well.  I got a C+ for other reasons, not because he's too hard for anything.  Love the turkish accent.  I recommend printing out the powerpoints before class and taking notes right on them; that really helped me when I started doing it later in the semester.

Professor Ozbeklik literally teaches right from the book, so attendance is not mandatory.  His finals are relatively easy, and there is barely any work assigned. He is very kind and all his lectures are very clear. If you do the minimal work, you will get a good grade.

Three words: PIZZA AND PEPSI. He is a great man.  This subject is totally not my thing, so the extra credit assignment (read Freakonomics and write a report) TRULY helped especially since this is a CMC GE req.  Ozbeklik is very helpful, and clear about this alien subject. Also, I love his accent and his love for the Buckeyes.

Tough subject for me, but Ozbeklik really does work hard to help you understand the material. It's a time-consuming course by nature, but he helps by giving you quiz questions in advance as well as study guides. Very enthusiastic. Highly recommended for non-econ types.
Really great professor for Econ50. Not too much work, and he gives you study guides for tests and quizes. Highly recommended.

Very enthusiastic Econ 50 professor. Take this class if you want a good understanding of the basics of Economics. He will bend over backward to show you how to understand something, and is almost always available for help outside of class. He gives the quiz questions before the quizzes, and so if you do a little bit of work, you should do well.
No Comments
Nice guy, lectures straight off power points and out of the book. Fine for an Econ 50 teacher. He tries to adapt to fit some of the needs of the students.

I had him for FHS Religion and Modernity and for a student who was not very interested in studying religion, the course topics really stuck with me long after that semester. The readings are hard to get through since they are archaic, yet the conversations during class made the reading make sense and he really wanted us to understand the content.

Took Professor Lincoln for Econ 101 and it was hands down one of my favorite classes I've taken so far. During office hours he breaks things down very clearly and if you do the homework + practice questions properly it won't be difficult to do well. Also just a really nice easygoing person to be around!

Professor Lincoln is one of my favorite professors. His lecturing may be a bit dry at first, but he gets better as the semester progresses and tells fun stories that help you remember things too. When he comes across a particularly difficult topic that he knows students usually get stuck on, he waits for students to ask questions.

He gives you A LOT of practice, so it's easy to overlook or skip problems. DO ALL THE PROBLEMS IF YOU WANT TO DO WELL ON THE EXAM. I found it to be a difficult course that required a lot of hard work, but I enjoyed the course because Lincoln truly cares about his students. Hands down nicest professor, but don't expect generous grading.

The class attendance was optional and every day was just lectures never did worksheets or activities (so it was boring). Professor Lincoln is very helpful during office hours! Exams were difficult! Make sure to do the practice problems regularly after every lecture (even though they aren't required) so that you can apply what you learned.

If you get the chance to take Professor Lincoln, then jump on it. Teaches you all the basic concepts and makes learning them feel natural. Really helpful in office hours so it is always worth it to go. Likes to throw in a joke every now and again but the lectures are mainly content. With some light studying and reviewing-the tests are very passable

Great professor with crystal-clear lectures (he posts slides online). Tests are easy if you review the material. Not a lot of work and doesn't require you to read the textbook. Answers questions directly and helpful in office hours, however lectures can move pretty fast and be very dry (he just reads off the slides).

Professor Lincoln was great, however, expect heavy lectures and over 70% of your grade to be from two tests. He is the most clear and accessible professor however, and teaches you so many valuable concepts.

If you take the initiative to do the practice problems, understand the homework, study the lecture slides, and go to office hours, the tests aren't that hard and you will definitely succeed. Helpful in office hours without ever giving the answer. Not a terribly difficult class, but he is a very effective teacher and I learned a lot.
Great Prof! He is always approachable and can explain concepts very clearly - this is also due to the clear structure of his class. I would for sure take any other class that he teaches.

Super nice professor! Very straightforward, with clear expectations. He sometimes gives interesting examples and stories. He is very patient, and would not mind explain concepts in more details during office hours.
he's cool...i loved his random stories especially about the one on persian rugs

Lincoln is a brilliant professor. He is a really smart man. Class can get a bit boring, but its because he has a blood circulation condition which makes him get exhausted easily. However, he is extremely clear. He is great at both explaining the intuition and mathematics behind economics. Take his class.

He is an adorable professor. Very clear and straight forward. Curves his class and you are most likely to get an A if you follow his instructions and understand the practice problems. He is very intelligent and always willing to help. He holds tons of office hours and is pretty chill. Take him for Micro and you won't regret it even once.

Professor Lincoln is a legend and a half. He makes Micro so straight forward and is very clear about what is expected of you on tests. There are occassional problem sets that are helpful. 10/10 would recommend.

Professor Lincoln does a great job teaching his students the theory and applications of econometrics. He makes a very difficult subject interesting and very understandable. A great addition to the econ department.

He makes boring topics interesting. Graded on a few essays, take home midterm, and final. He is so nice and very accessible outside of class. Easy grader but you learn the material very well. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

There's quite a bit of reading for Prof. Kesler's class but they are very comprehensible even for students without previous U.S. government knowledge. The class can be a little boring if you're not into gov but he's a good gov20 choice, not too harsh of a grader

Probably my favorite professor! Lots of great readings for the class- no textbook, which makes class very interesting. While known for his conservative works, Professor Kesler is very knowledgeable and open to discuss current events in a very rational way during office hours. I cannot recommend a professor more.

Professor Kesler is great. His classes can be lecture heavy but filled with insightful arguments and engaging material. Grades consist of 3 papers and a final. He is super helpful during office hours and will read drafts of papers you wrote beforehand to help you with your final submission. Straightforward and clearly outlined expectations for a GE

Professor Kesler is a wonderful, wonderful professor. This is the second semester I have taken a class with him and I want to take more. I sit there, listening to him lecture for nearly three hours but I am engaged the entire time. He is compelling and interesting and so intelligent. I encourage everyone to take a class with this professor. 11/10.

Kesler is a government department dinosaur engrained in the prevailing traditional school of thought on American political science. Kesler is a wealth of knowledge, but his lectures often take 15-30 minute tangents and don't engage the material in critical, meaningful ways. Easy grading and loose expectations make Kesler a good easy GOV20 option
He is the most wonderful professor in my life. Easy to understand, beautiful eyes to listen to student's comments. I highly recommend him.

Assigns a ton of reading, but he's an easy grader. If you're not motivated to prioritise the class you can still get a decent grade without doing the readings. Funny guy, obviously been there awhile. Took us out to pizza before the final, very approachable and easy to talk to. Understands if gov isn't your major. Teaches interesting concepts.

Prof. Kesler is a very helpful and nice guy. Very approachable to students and don't make you stupid or intimidated to talk to him and ask him questions. There's not too much discussions going on in his class, but his lectures are really enlightening. Not too much workload either! Good for a non gov major student to take gov 20 with!
Most brilliant professor I've ever encountered. simplifies incredibly complex topics on a daily basis. Almost problematic how easy he makes teaching an intro class look. Highly recommend.

I had Kesler for Gov 20 (Intro to American Politics) Fall '09. The class is pretty easy - just to do all the reading. There's a short paper (~2 pages), a longer paper (~5 pages), a midterm, and the final. Readings are tested on the exams. I would recommend going to class, though he can be pretty dry. I still learned a lot though! :)

He's harder for some easier for others, but overall I think he's reasonable. Sometimes lectures get boring. this isn't really a discussion class. He really likes to talk, sometimes about himself. He's pretty accomplished and really smart. You don't really have to do the readings, but they help. He brings out the most important points for sure. If y

reasonable amount of reading and somewhat interesting class dicussions. grade is based on a midterm, paper, and final, limiting how well (and how poorly) you can do in the course. almost every student earns a B. kesler is a genius, yet his lectures are often dry and boring. he's a really nice guy though.
He is the best professor at CMC: Brilliant, funny, etc.  His lectures should be published.

Nice prof, but lectures are really hard to sit through, and grade is based on midterm, essay, and final, which makes it hard to earn a good grade if you screw up once. Cracks jokes every once in a while, but they're not exactly the best.

very easy to understand lectures (sometimes a little hard to sit through though), grade is based off of 2 tests and 1 paper though which makes it harder to do well but requires less work throughout the semester
No Comments
Great prof.  Smart, charming, and laid-back.
Honors seminar: lots of reading but interesting discussions and only 3 papers througout the semester. Kesler is a cool guy. And he even took us out for pizza.
Excellent prof, even though I forgot most of what I learned already... Oh and papers over breaks are not fun...unless you're **** at the time.
quality prof
No Comments
good professor, conservative of course.
laughs at all his own jokes!

Easily one of the coolest professors at CMC. Lectures are given to the students and class time became office hours. Typical math exams turned into essay exams, which he might continue doing when we get back on campus. Didn't really retain any material but a fun class for math GE

I did not like prof Nelson. Not only attendance wasn't required, he literally did not give lectures. He just dropped a lecture pdf and students read it themselves. It is very easy to get an A, but you won't learn a single thing.

Nelson lectures really quietly and kinda covers the whiteboard while he writes. He makes up some concepts that you have to learn for the class, but since he created them, if you get confused you can't even look to other sources for another explanation of the topic.

He's an awkward dude, but he teaches math well. He lectures fast and often makes simple mistakes, but he is very gracious when his students correct him. His lectures are clear with plenty of examples to help you understand. You can go the whole semester only saying 3 words "Thank you professor". Basically, its all lecture.

I took Calculus IIA which is intended for freshman who took ap calc. This class was like half review half new content. Nelson lectures fast and the material can be tricky at times, but if you go to the QCL and do the homework you will be fine. The grading scale makes it easy to do well in the class.

Nelson talks super quietly and rushes through the lectures. But don't fret, this is an easy A. You can earn a plethora of extra credit points on the homework and tests, such that you can literally fail the final and still get an A.

A solid choice for a math professor. It is obvious professor Nelson is passionate about mathematics and you can see his face light up when he gets going on something. Really humble guy, make use of his office hours he is ready to help. Professor Nelson has his own textbook for this class and it is AMAZING. I reference it constantly.

Professor Nelson is currently my favorite teacher CMC. He is extremely kind and helpful outside of class. He provides extensive contact info on the syllabus to ensure that he can provide guidance to all students seeking it. I have never worried about feeling lost in his course, even though the material is difficult because of how well he teaches.

Linear Algebra with Professor Nelson is definitely a great experience as far as you don't miss out. It is very chill in grading, however, it is not as easy as any calculus class. Expect a lot of twisted homework, speedy lectures, and pretty difficult tests. Sam is a very nice professor and definitely one of the best in CMC. Definitely recommend!

Really nice guy, super helpful in office hours. Homework every week (except before midterms). Extra points on homework will save your grade. Writes on board, you just have to copy it. Easy to skip class. Sit up front if you can, he can be hard to hear in some classrooms. Has his own textbook, gives it to you for free. Get ready for math jokes.

Taken CalculusII with professor Nelson, here's what I want to say: he is a pure mathematical genius and a CMC gem. As he says, there are 70% of Math that can be told easy way, but it is not yet told by other professors, and there is the rest 30% that is just plain hard. He makes concepts so simple, but efficient, and is always there to help. Take!

Relatively innovative but chill grading system; no need to buy textbook; need to pay close attention to his lectures or you will find it hard to understand what's going on. But once you start to follow, you'll start to appreciate how smart he is. Inspired by him to learn more about topology, knot theory and higher algebra. He is really cool.

I was a little thrown off at the beginning with the notation and proof-heavy questions, but it is honestly standard practice in math at the 5Cs. Professor Nelson has probably the most favorable grading system I have ever had, and was generally very clear in his lectures. His sense of humor is subtle and he's quiet, so try to sit close to the front.

DO NOT TAKE CALC 2 UNLESS YOU HAVE TO. One of the hardest classes at CMC. His quizzes are pretty easy. If you have not taken AP Calc BC expect to work your butt off. Both midterms were fair. The concepts on the final were fair but he made it unnecessarily hard. Do not buy textbook (you will never use it).
Simple the WORST! Talked about topology all the time! God I'm here to learn Calculus!

Terrible class. Worst class I have ever had at 5C. I personally am a big fan of mathematics but this course is so boring from the beginning to the end. He probably thought he was super cool but he's so lame.
