But I spent hours after class with Professor Wells in office hours and tutoring and he was always willing to put in the time with me and sit with me until I got it.

Prof Wells really cared about his students and their understanding of the topic. Although the information was not always explicitly clear throughout the lectures, he would dedicate a lot of his time out of class to make sure his students understood. Hard class but you just have to put in the effort.

Professor Wells goes on rambling lectures, never answers questions, makes things more confusing than they should be, and will jump at every opportunity to talk about his horses. 3/2 majors, don't take physics with him! You can catch him outside class for awkward, silent meetings. Terrible teacher, no help at all.

honestly professor wells is such a great dude! he has good intentions and is willing to help whenever you need it. i learned most of this stuff outside of class with tutoring and office hours, and he is extremely helpful when you reach out. tests based off in class problems and homework! this class was definitely challenging though

How do I even begin? This class made me lose my will to live. His lectures consisted of him reading directly off his PowerPoint, & the lectures had no correlation to the material on the homework or the exams. He yelled at us for not knowing and understanding material. If you want to learn, you have to teach yourself. This class made me miserable.

What an awful introduction to college physics! In his defense, Professor Wells seems to be knowledgeable about the topics, but he cannot teach in the slightest. The class assumes a great amount of prior knowledge and goes far beyond its MATH30 pre/corequisites. Never take this class, it's tedious, convoluted, and nothing is explained. Ugh.

I have personally never had such an awful academic experience. This class shattered my love for physics. I came in as a confident physics major but this prof made me doubt myself in every way possible. He made me feel inferior, unintelligent and incapable. He does not teach the material and yells at his students for not understanding the textbook.

The class content was not hard for a person who took Physics in High school but Professor Wells made it so tough. He doesn't put much emphasis on Quizzes and they are a bit easy. His Homeworks are long, tough. His midterms are very very tough. The good thing is that he curves the final grade, which makes people better grades than they expected.

I did worse than I feel I should have considering I took two years pf physics in high school. Doesn't make intro physics very accessible and is unapproachable outside of class. There is tutoring which helps. Material overall wasn't covered very well in lecture and you basically have to study yourself using the book. Phys 34 is a way better class.
He doesn't care about you or your grade. get ready to hustle on your own or die trying

Passionate about physics? Like having a high GPA? ... prepare to have that ruined if you take a class with Wells. I learned more in tutoring then in class, office hours were very unhelpful. Professor Wells taught me less then the textbook. Constantly acted like he wasn't passionate about his teaching or his students .

He made the class more difficult than it's supposed to be. Your grade for the class is basically your overall grade from midterms/final. Homework and quizzes and labs don't really matter. Not helpful during office hours. A ton of work is assigned, not helpful though. Rip 3-2.
It doesn't matter how much you love physics, if you take his class he will take that love and feed it to his horses. He is a mean man and a bad prof. He makes me sad.

He is not as bad as everyone makes him out to be! Yes, he yelled at the class a few times, BUT I'm not going to lie, our class can be very disrespectful and rude. You do have to read from the textbook quite a bit, but he breaks up the sections so it is very manageable. He is also helpful in office hours. You get what you put in from this class.

Does not go over the material in class, you have to read and take a reading quizzes before each class. He asks the class questions on the reading during class and gets irritated easily. I learned everything through tutors and re-reading the text book. One positive is that the exams are fairly short and easy.

Best physics prof at Keck, hands down. Actually wants to see you succeed instead of weeding students out. Phys 35 content is not an easy class, but Setter goes slow and makes sure it makes sense. You do have to go to class in order to succeed here, though, because the material is confusing. His lectures are good. Nice guy
Professor Setter is the best instructor I have ever had. He is so welcoming about questions that I always had all the comfort in the world asking until I fully understood the topic.

My favorite professor at CMC by far -- he was very extremely helpful in office hours, explained material with utmost clarity, and made sure to drill a topic in your head instead of mindlessly moving on. Make sure to participate and complete homeworks systematically and you'll perform very well in the class!

Great online teaching, lectures are clear and interesting, relevant to homework, answers questions well. Very accessible outside of class (office hours, email, Slack channel), worth it to attend office hours as homeworks are long and sometimes difficult. I learned a lot, even though the class was online this semester.

Professor Setter is kind, genuine, and clearly excited about what he teaches (physics). I highly recommend his class to anyone who is interested in physics. Be prepared, his class will challenge you, particularly homework assignments! However, exams are very fair and he is lenient with partial credit.

Setter is a solid choice for phys30/31. It's clear he loves physics and wants you to understand it and likes questions. Sometimes lecture isn't the most helpful bc we spend so long on one example or deriving formulas but the content was mostly relevant. Written and online HW every week with corrections and exams are fair (w corrections too).

Prof Leconte is a barely-average instructor who expects exceptional work from all students. Nit-picky and arrogant, hes the kind of professor who just doesnt want to give As in what is already a tough subject.

I would strongly recommend not taking class with professor leconte if you have other options. He is not understanding and structures his class to be unnecessarily challenging. When you go to office hours, he plays guessing games and is rarely direct about if you are on the right track-- he thinks this is valuable for learning but it is frustrating.

Aaron is a great prof who truly cares for his students and wants them to do well and learn. He wants you to be a true scientist and learn to think for yourself. I learned a lot in his class and he gives great feedback but is also a tough grader, has strict class policies, and gives few A's. But overall, the learning experience was good.
This class was incredibly difficult. The professor was knowledgeable, but when going to his office hours he was patronizing. He made it clear he was way smarter than you and not very helpful.
He is incredibly smart and very qualified to teach! Sorta sassy sometimes but he really cares that all his students are understanding the material.

The IBC problem sets were pretty packed, but were helpful. He's a great lecturer, sometimes goes fast but he's clear and always willing to answer questions. I felt he cared about students and was helpful in office hours and he gave exam review sessions. His grading is a bit picky though. Definitely not a boring prof. Lab was pretty good :)

Leconte is quirky and hilarious, so he can make boring chemistry topics fun. He expects a lot from his students and is nit-picky with grading. He goes through concepts really fast but explains things clearly. At office hours, he is even more clear and helpful. His tests are straightforward with few curve-balls. His review sessions are very helpful

Very good lecturer, but not willing to answer super specific questions in class. His office hours are the best; very personable and quirky. He'll support you when you need it. Tests are easy, but you need to be on your toes at all times. He's great, just get ready to work.

I really struggled with this class in the beginning but Professor Leconte made a point to reach out and help me get back on track. He's a little odd, but very funny in lectures. Overall, a very approachable person and passionate about his teaching.

Great lecturer. He goes through concepts really fast though and is reluctant to answer questions extensively in class. His problem sets are also time-intensive. However, he is very patient and approachable during his office hours. You will work your butt off but you will also learn tons.

Professor Leconte is amazing! He is, hands down, one of the best professors I have ever had. Although he can go through material a little too quickly at times, he explains things in a way that is very clear and easy to understand. He is also very good about explaining things outside of class and he is very available during office hours.

I LOVE Aaron. I took him for IBC and he is fabulous. He goes into super intense detail on the material and expects so much from you, but it makes you such a better student and so much smarter. He encourages great class participation too, which make every lecture interesting!

He's a smart guy but tests are insanely hard. Goes pretty fast during lectures making it hard to keep up. Sometimes makes you feel a little out of place when asking a question, but overall very helpful if you ask in recitation/office hours. Problem sets are a nightmare.
Helpful, but one of the hardest classes I've ever taken and assigns ridiculous amounts of work.

Threre are daily quizzes on the readings which are easy and the readings are pretty interesting most of the time. The discussions we have in class are very eye-opening. If you're not a history major, it may take some time getting used to her essay format, but go to her office hours and she helps a lot. 4 essays for the semester, but it takes effort

The best class I have ever taken at CMC with the best professor I have ever taken. The class was engaging and Professor Selig was kind and really cares about her students. The material was incredibly interesting and I learned so much. I can't recommend this class enough!

Professor Selig is amazing, you won't regret taking her class. She made the class extremely accommodating, and even more so after students expressed feedback mid-way through. She's very receptive to student feedback, and class discussions are always interesting. There were daily readings, but it's manageable. She did her best to help students.

Professor Selig is one of the most genuine, caring professors I've ever had. After students expressed being overwhelmed with the online semester, she modified the course syllabus to be as accommodating as possible. There are multiple daily readings, but they are all very interesting, so the don't fear the reading workload!

I'm so happy I took FHS with Professor Selig! I never would've thought to take a Gender Studies class, but it ended up being very eye-opening and engaging material. There was quite a bit of reading but it's all very interesting and prevalent to everyday life. Our grade was comprised of participation and four, five-page essays about the readings.

By far the most kind professor. A lot of reviews say she's easy (mostly true ), but I'm not a history major so I had to work harder to do well on the essays. I went to go see her for every essay and it was 100% worth it. She is clearly so passionate about what she teaches and that carries over into discussion. Fair amount of reading, but doable.

Prof Selig is compassionate and caring. She makes her class discussions accessible to everyone, and I always looked forward to coming to class. She is a fair grader, and I found my meetings with her about paper topics helpful. Prof Selig's class really inspired an interest in history for me, and I wish I could take another class with her!
So inspirational, compassionate and dedicated. A really talented Professor, and gives great feedback on writing. Very flexible with writing assignments as well.

Professor Selig was an incredible professor that provided readings that were both fascinating and intellectually stimulating. The papers are very reasonable (5 pages), 4 per semester, and you have about 3-4 weeks to complete each paper. Her grading is fair and you receive the grade that you deserve based on how much work you place in the class.

Selig is AMAZING!! This has been by far my favorite class and favorite professor at CMC. She got me so interested in the topic of gender that I might do a gender sequence. She isn't an easy grader on papers (but isn't too hard either) and is very helpful and accommodating. TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU CAN!!

Prof. Selig is an amazing professor! I had Gender and Society (FHS) with her as a freshman. She is very open minded and doesn't teach the class from a specific angle or viewpoint. Class is very discussion-based. She is willing to work with you in office hours to help you improve your writing and will even just give recs for course registration.

Selig is AMAZING! take her FWS class if you have a chance. She is a sweet and loving person and she is always willing to help you improve your writing. She really knows her stuff and every class is interesting!

It's been over ten years since I had my first class with Professor Selig, but it changed my life. It was called "Currents of Reform" and was offered as an honors history class for freshmen in the fall of 2001. Amazing class, and Professor Selig's passion for the subject couldn't help but sweep us up as well.

One of the nicest, most caring, and passionate teachers on campus! I wish I had known about her sooner. She provides lots of flexibility with assignments to ensure you are able to write about topics that interest you. Very discussion based class style. If you're interested in the content of the courses she teaches, take them!

Professor Selig is awesome.  She's warm and funny and easily approachable. She's passionate about the material and helps her students to be as well. The assigned readings for the most part are fascinating.  And I love her teaching style - very down to earth. She's definitely one of the coolest professors I've come across at the Claremont Colleges.

Professor Selig talks very quickly because she is so passionate about what she teaches.  She tries to fit too much into each individual class and she spends a lot of time giving the class historical examples of things that we may or may not enjoy.  Examples include songs and film clips that at least make class manageable.
Wonderful teacher!  Caring, super smart, and very helpful. She picks wonderful reading materials.

Selig is the best. She is so cute, knowledgeable, and draws you into the subject like none other. Very helpful in office hours. History 81 is the best survey class ever if you want American history. Best recommendations...take her!!!
Amazing course.  Couldn't reccomend her highly enough.
Selig Rocks!  Her class is a lot of reading and writing but she takes the time to write lots of comments and give you feedback on papers.  She really cares what students get out of her class!
great prof, very passionate about the subjects she teaches.
No Comments
Very shifty grading.  Beware, she does not have grading standards, but reserves the right to establish them after the fact.
Talks fast, but its worth listening to
No Comments

Professor Von Hallberg is easily my favorite professor and my favorite class. He asks only for 2 150 paragraphs related to the reading each week, and 3 5 page essays. Really teaches you how to connect to what you write and to be more concise, classes are discussion heavy and very interesting.

Don't take his FWS. He is a nice guy, genuinely I like him as a person. However, as a teacher, he is quite vague with what he wants (as in no prompts), especially in terms of essays (which are 5 pages). I haven't learned anything in terms of being a better writer, which makes the class a waste of time.

I really like Von Hallberg. Be ready to read a decent amount and be engaged in class. Meet with his in office hours about your paper and he will help. He is a tough grader but makes you want to write well. He likes personal writing.

I took his Spy Films class and really enjoyed it. The movie choices are solid and we discussed them in class, which I loved. Discussions were interesting and von Hallberg encouraged everyone to speak. He is super understanding about assignments and grades, and overall wants you to do well in his class. He is always open to meet and offer advice.

Took him for Spy Films, thought it would be a cool class. His selection of films was stale, the discussions were cringy, and he didn't encourage diverse opinions. PoC, save yourself the pain and don't take any of his classes.
Great professor- take him if you have the chance.

Von Hallberg is the best lit professor in all the 5 Cs. I'd HIGHLY recommend his poetry classes. He's super knowledgable, kind, and respects his students. He isn't a hard grader and is very understanding about extensions on essays. Often goes on tangents but they're all very enjoyable. You learn much more than what you signed up for.

Great professor and interesting class. Very clear and helpful during class and in office hours. Requires 4 papers throughout the semester but papers are interesting and not just "run of the mill". Really lets you express yourself in this class. Would recommend this class to anybody who is interested in developing creative writing skills.

His lectures are awesome and he is very accessible. I've barely used the textbook because his lectures are so good. But, Phys33 is physics for engineering/physics majors so it's pretty time consuming and the homework is hard. The class is also pretty test heavy with three "midterms" and a final exam making up the majority of our grade.

Professor Landsberg is for you if you actually want to learn physics. Take this class if you are ready to invest around an hour a day to work on physics, and will actually enjoy it. Landsberg truly cares about his students and is very approachable in office hours. He explains things quite clearly and will not talk down to you. Loved this class.
Cares about your interest in physics
The best professor I've had at the 5cs. He's a lot of work, but if you keep up you will actually learn physics, which is pretty cool.

Took him because there weren't any other alternatives. Pleasantly surprised. Interesting guy, very VERY organised, lectures are most definitely rehearsed. Can seem condescending during lectures, was not very respected by some of my classmates, there's a lot of homework and he expects you to study ("train like an athlete") at least 1.5-2 hours a day

On most test questions you will need to give a free body diagram, have your coordinates right etc. to receive full credit. DO IT! Best way to review for midterms and exams are to redo all hw questions until you master them. Very helpful during office hours. Will talk you through what he wants to see/what you did wrong on the test. Overall good prof

Very very organized.  Great teacher though extremely  difficult. Very helpful.  Gives lecture notes out, but for that reason does not give study guides.  Good guy, if you are interested in Physics take him, if it is just an elective id look somewhere else.
He is very enthusiastic, and he teaches very well!
Really helpful and clear, his powerpoints are excellent.

Landsberg is a GREAT prof. His lectures are clear and make hard stuff really easy. Expect lots of really annoying problem sets, but they do help you out on tests. Midterms are straightforward, but he grades pretty tough. Always helpful and willing to explain in a way that you can understand. Take his class!

Adam is the BEST powerpoint presenter you will EVER encounter. He can perfectly answer questions and is a competent, fair grader. Very strait forward. He is not easy though. If you care AT ALL about being a good physicist/scientist/person, don't miss him.

Landsberg is hilarious in that he is so painfully organized.  He really knows what he's teaching and is very clear in explanations.  He gives you print outs of all of his powerpoint lectures, which was a plus.  No need for book reading here!  Problem sets are a pain, but overall it could have been much worse. He's easily the best choice for phyics.

Prof Grant cares a lot, is really organized, and teaches the class well. But it's a lot of work (albeit very little test-work), and in lectures, she can get frustrated if students don't latch onto concepts immediately. Overall though, you could do a lot worse with a level two.
Professor Grant really cares. She's tough, and I took 101 in a virtual capacity, but she was so accessible. The A is attainable, you just need to put in the work.

All the qualitative participation elements you DON'T expect in an econ course + the rigid quantitative grading you DO expect in an econ course. Makes for a confused and dysfunctional class. Even the participation elements like the frustating emphasis on 'intuition' feel like gimmicks. doesnt help your understanding, just pulls your grade down

Avoid at all costs! She is nice enough in class but from the constant assessments and textbook reading, that she grades undyingly strict, she makes the class unbearable. Requires you to answer her tests using "intuition" which is code for say it exactly how I want you to or else you won't get any credit. You should save yourself the pain.

Professor Grant really cares about your success. She wants you to become a more thoughtful economics student and a better person. When you talk to her in office hours, this becomes clear. The class was a little slow at times, but you should definitely take a class with Grant if you have the chance. One of the nicer people I've ever met. Seriously.

Econ101 is lecture heavy she's great at explaining the intuition and giving you real-life examples & detailed notes. Tests are challenging and mathy but there are weekly open-book quizzes that help you know if you're falling behind. She curves too. Genuinely cares about her students. Easily one of my favorite professors at CMC!

Professor Grant is my fav! I wouldn't say her class is "easy," but she does a great job of explaining the intuition of concepts you will need in future Econ classes. The best part is she is so approachable and really cares about you succeeding, especially if you show that you care. Weekly open-note quizzes, three problem sets and three exams total.

Grant is overall a nice lady, just not the best prof. This class was trying to do too many things, and was not very organized. There were two "quizzes" and we had little-to-no resources to actually know the material. She sometimes gave us study-guides with wrong answers. There are alot of readings, which i liked. Final is a paper, which is not bad

Professor Grant is an excellent teacher. She is accessible outside of class, helpful during office hours, and extremely friendly. Her class is extremely difficult so be prepared to work hard. Once a week, during class she hands out a worksheet, it is graded for accuracy and also counts for participation with no make up. Tests are very rigorous.
Took Professor Grant's class for Micro and loved it. Very math heavy but she explains it very well. Tests can be slightly challenging but are extremely fair. 10/10 would recommend this class

Professor Grant is the best!! She is incredibly caring to all her students and sincerely wants everyone to succeed. Expectations are straight forward. Exams are very math/algebra heavy. Weekly open note "quizzes" that you can ask for help. She has been one of my favorite professors at CMC so far! She made me love micro, 10/10 recommend to anyone :)

Professor Burdekin is a very good professor. His lectures are very interesting. He is very clear and knowledgeable. He is very accessible outside of class, willing to meet outside of office hours, and is very responsive to questions over email. Exams based on class material. If you go to every class and take good notes you will succeed.

This class is my favorite econ class to date. Kind of an intersection between history and econ. I feel so much more informed and able to participate in finance and current event discussions. His tests are right out of the lectures, if you pay attention and take good notes review should be straight forward. He was lovely to speak with in office hrs.

If you are willing to come to class and be present in class, meaning take notes of EVERYTHING he says, every example/scenario, and ask questions as they come up, you will do well. No homework, 3 non-cumulative tests, and 1 presentation. He responds to emails about practice problems within 10-30 minutes even on weekends. Kind, knowledgeable, caring.

If you come to EVERY class you will get all the material you need to ace the tests. There is no participation or homework, just exams which are very doable if you take good notes in class. He is so available after class and very helpful in office hours. I had him early in the morning in Fall of 2021 and this was my favorite in person class.

Professor Burdekin is my favorite Econ professor at CMC so far! His lectures were extremely clear and focused mostly on the intuition of theoretical concepts. There is barely any math in the class, although that can sometimes make the concepts harder to grasp. No homework or problem sets, just three exams and one project. Go to office hours!

Professor Burdekin was the best class I have taken so far in my Economics major at CMC. He is likely the professor who has most inspired me to go further in my Economics degree. His ECON102 course is focused on learning. He has 0 homework assignments, problem sets, or projects. 3 midterms, talk to him in office hours, he'll give you the answers.

No homework, good professor, and clear grading criteria. Class is just hard because it is just midterms. Overall, glad I am taking it. He wants kids to do well, and makes some funny jokes. One downside: man has really bad hand writing. But, still good class and interesting stuff.

Great class. Prof burdekin is a really nice professor and if you work hard enough and study your notes it's possible to get an A in the class. Extremely helpful in office hours. Wants students to do well

Somewhat confusing in class lectures and often goes through material too fast but incredibly helpful during office hours. An A is definitely possible if you go to class and office hours for clarification.
He is awesome, Very helpful and clear, take his class
He is an amazing professor. He teaches the material very well. If you don't understand the material he taught in class, go to his office hours and you will feel confident again. TAKE HIS CLASS

econ 180 is the seminar that goes with thesis. burdekin is the nicest guy in the world, and he's always willing to help. a lot of professors at cmc make you see them in person before they'll be helpful at all, but burdekin reads through e-mails and replies thoroughly. that's amazingly convenient and it shows how much he cares about his students!

Burdekin is a decent teacher and a nice guy. his class is a little dry, but there is minimal hw and the tests are graded on a giant curve. that being said, people will literally fail his class, but if you study hard for just 2 exams and a final, you'll do well. I would recommend him, but i would not discourage someone from taking a different class.

Professor Burdekin is a very intelligent and articulate teacher.  If you do not pay attention in class your notes are meaningless once you get around to them.  His tests are challenging but everything is very straight forward.  The presentation is kind of a joke and putting in the time generally results in a good score.

I had a hard time with Burdekin.  As a visual learner, I learn by taking notes.  He uses up/down arrows to indicate changes in economic indicators, and in a whirlwind he changes all the arrows without allowing note-takers time to copy it down.
No Comments
No Comments
Puts the material in your lap for you. Understand the graphs during class and the practice tests inside and out and there is no way you can not pull a B+ or higher.

The lectures can get a little boring but otherwise the class and prof Gelman are great! Tests are not that hard and they don't make up a lot of your grade. Group projects influence your grade a lot so make sure you're ok with that.
Gelman is great. Very smart guy (went to UMich and did banking at Deutsche) and has very clear lectures. Great professor if you are interested in learning about Macro.

Professor Hurley is AMAZING and probably my favorite professor at CMC. While you should be prepared to put work into his class, he cares so much for all his students and makes an effort to get everyone participating and feel included. I cannot recommend him enough, and you will learn how to think and engage with others!

I LOVE this guy. He somehow gets everyone to comfortably participate every class. Class is TOPICAL! We reference modern issues and connect it to the texts, which themselves are solid reads. He is a sweet, hilarious jolly man. Easy to talk to, you'll find that you spend more time than you think chatting with him! You just have to take his class!!

Professor Hurley's classes covers a wide breadth of philosophy, both historically and contemporarily. I learned a massive deal from having taken his class, and lessons were always extremely interesting. A lot of positive discussion happens constantly in his lessons - you change without knowing it through taking his class.

Hurley is an amazing professor. His classes are fascinating and he is a great discussion leader and an extremely knowledgeable man. Not only that, but he is also kind, thoughtful, and jovial. Any time spent with Hurley is time well spent.

Hurley is one of the best professors at CMC. He's incredibly kind, thoughtful, and wants to help you understand the material. I've never enjoyed class discussion as much as I did in his class. He gets everyone involved, so you better have done the reading, but I guarantee you, his class is worth it. He also happens to be pretty hilarious.

Hurley is a God (mostly serious). He's interesting enough to make a 3 hour seminar fly by. If you take him, you'll have a lot of great discussions. Go to his office hours as much as possible - I didn't start going until the end of the tutorials and wished I had gone far more than I did. I was pleasantly surprised by my final grade.

Paul Hurley is by far the best professor at CMC. Unparalleled ability to orchestrate powerful and engaging discussion. Every reading and assignment was well thought out, curated, fascinating, and world-view changing. Will take every opportunity to take a class with him.
Best prof at CMC.  Enlightened my thought.  Most valuable class in terms of understanding life.
Best prof at school  Makes things incredibly clear.  He can change the way you think.

Hurley is a truly amazing professor.  He clearly loves what he teaches, and he loves to help you understand it.  Incredibly helpful if you need it.  His lectures are interesting, and he is engaging and laid-back.  His class isn't easy but he gives you good feedback and it's easy to improve.  Definitely take one of his classes if you can.

Take a class from this professor if you can. He is a nice man, a good professor, and has a keen understanding of human beings. His lectures are fascinating and it's like he's not even trying he's so good.

I found her unclear + a little passive aggressive. She uses a lot of shame + if its silent for a sec she says if you all dont have anything to say on THIS, I dont know what to say. She has office hours but its a task to get her to read drafts. Personally one of the worst fits, but if youre resilient + can do the longgg readings youll be good.

Simply put, Prof McAniff represents the best CMC has to offer. He is not teacher but a mentor; he will help you unlock your full potential. Classes are not about gaining grades but about learning material that will help you thrive in life. Classes are relevant, tough but so rewarding. Bring a note book to write down all his life secrets and wisdom

Best class I have taken at CMC, hands down. Professor McAniff cares incredibly about his students and really tries to emphasize topics that you will directly use in the real world. Very knowledgeable, and a nice and personal professor that is willing to put in a lot of extra time to help his students out. Tall workload, but he is a fair grader.

Professor McAniff is so kind. He really takes the time to get to know students, and tries to make himself as accessible as possible. He also encourages questions, and is focused on practical use of the material. Would definitely recommend.

McAniff is very caring and invested in student's learning -- he wants you to apply the material to the real world, not just get an "A." I find him very personable but wish class was more organized. His anecdotes are interesting, he links business news to concepts in class, gives great life advice, and recognizes people with diverse backgrounds.

Prof Kanaya is hilarious and quirky (in a great way) - I will really miss classes with her. Classes are interactive and feel like a direct dialogue with her. I took the class as a GE and I'm not super interested in dev psych but despite this, I was never unexcited to go to class and learned a lot. Also nice that you get tested as you go - no final!

Great prof. Attendance is really important and especially being on time. There are online quizzes that make up a ton of your grade so do well on them. Sona Systems deadlines are super important to her as well.

It's definitely a lot of work for an Intro class/GE, but she prepares you well if you wind up majoring. She's clearly knowledgeable and really helpful during office hours even after the semester has ended.

One of the worst profs I've had at CMC. Very unhelpful at office hours and via email - for most of the short essays, you have to guess her grading criteria. Very picky with her grading and has prompts that are too open ended. If asked for specifications, she answers vaguely. Super frustrating to have, but you get out of class early most days

Great teacher. Graded on 5 short essays which weren't too hard if you pay attention in class and a final project. She is funny and keeps class interesting. She teaches what she has to teach and doesn't waste time in class. Always stayed after to chat or for extra help. Definitely a teacher to take!

She's one of the funniest professors I have had at CMC. I actually looked forward to ZOOM because of her energy. really strict about attendance and deadlines, though and a pretty tough grader for a GE.

It's not too much work for an intro class and she grades you on 5 short essays, but she has unclear/specific grading criteria that make getting an A pretty difficult. She is sarcastic and strict with participation. She's not super sensitive or nuanced with some of the topics in psych like mental disorders, gender, etc. so just be aware of that.
Shes sarcastic and has a lot of enthusiasm for the topic. She puts her lecture notes online but you still have to go to class to understand the assignments.

Kanaya's teaching style is fantastic. Very Powerpoint heavy.  Definitely print out the slides and take notes. She's also pretty hilarious.  Her grading and expectations are kind of unclear, and she doesn't offer that much help for you. Also, I think her grading is largely dependent on how much she likes you, so, show up to class and participate!

Super enthusiastic, puts a lot of effort into her classes.  Class is interesting, she uses a lot of videos and activities.  Her class is harder than I was expecting for Intro to Psych, you have to do a ton of memorization for tests and lots of obscure questions, grades papers fairly hard.  She's a great lady though, I would recommend her class.
enthusiastic and a fair grader
good teacher.
No Comments

I really liked her teaching style. She used a powerpoint, but was very energetic and added to it a lot. You should read the book. She covers a lot, but definitely not all test material in lecture. I had trouble getting the essays to the required length, though they were only 4-5 pgs. Sometimes it felt like the length didn't fit the style she wanted

She is very nice, and obviously passionate about her topic, but is a little inconsiderate about assignments, gives a paper assignment a week before it's due, based on the reading for the next week, so you're literally grappling to do a paper. Also, she assigns way too much reading that basically just say the same thing.

She only allows hand written notes. You get 3 extra days to turn in essays that you can use at any time which is helpful so you don't have to ask for an extension. Essays are straight forward. Final is either essay, test, or project (you choose which one). Very easy prof.

Prof Geismer is very nice and always tries to improve the quality & experience of class. Though her paper topics are weird. Office hours are too short. Despite following instructions closely, her feedback is contradictory to what she advises in office hours & she only judges grammar. She ummmmmmms a lot. You'll fail if you use the passive voice!

Fantastic teacher, super knowledgable, and really nice and fair. She's a super hard grader though--as in I'm a history major and the worst history essay grades I've ever gotten were from her. She also doesn't acknowledge whether your comments were right or not after you say them, so class is a bit daunting sometimes.

Geismer is one of my favorite professors at CMC! I took her Reagan Era history class which obviously discussed Reagan and his policies, but looked more broadly at the culture of the 1980s as well. I didn't feel that the class was skewed one way or the other politically as well. So sad she wont be on campus next year!!
Best history class I've taken at the 5Cs. She is always so willing to help and open to feedback. She is so, so passionate about the material. Take her classes!

MUST DO THE READING. MUST GO TO CLASS. She often uses 'guess what I'm thinking' to kick-start discussion, which sucks. But she challenges preconceived notions of U.S. history and is pretty supportive. She was my summer internship course adviser, helping me out when I needed one last-minute.
Excellent teacher. Knows a lot about American history and is a great discussion leader. Assigns a lot of reading and hard grader but you will learn a lot. Favorite class at CMC. Highly recommended

Geismer loves history. She also pushes her students. The class fundamentally changed the way I think. She doesn't lecture so reading is imperative to a beneficial experience. She is extremely helpful during her office hours, and is almost always available. Essentially if you work for her, you will love your experience, but she does expect a lot.
Fantastic teacher. great discussion leader and really knowledgeable about recent american history. will learn a lot. She is a hard grader and assigns a lot of reading though.

My favorite class in college so far! Class was entirely based on discussion, so be ready to have an opinion. She graded papers pretty hard, not impossible to get an A if you work. Helped me understand the modern politics and basic contemporary american history as well as teaching me to form my own opinion of historical events. very enlightening!

Prof. Raviv teaches game theory very abstractly, and you are forced to learn the material through extremely difficult problem sets and past midterms that don't accurately affect the upcoming ones. The grade breakdown was: 20% problem sets (5), 20% midterm 1, 20% midterm 2, 40% final. This was not good, considering the raw average on mid2 was a 58%.

Prof Raviv made stats interesting and easy to understand. The only issue is that he speaks very quickly, so it would be hard to keep up if you can't watch the recordings of class. Since it was online, exams were open note, which helped a ton. If it wasn't open note, it would be harder but still okay bc you get a formula sheet. A solid choice.

Raviv genuinely cares so much about you if you make an effort in class, show up to office hours, and take him up on one of his opportunities for a meal. He even bumped my grade up to an A after exams were over because he gave another person points back for the same question on the final. I enjoyed him so much, he's now my advisor.
Provides you with a lot of resources: practice tests, textbooks, lectures. However, he has a very thick accent and does not teach the subject very well.

Professor Raviv is a great professor! Although his lectures are fast and he won't give you answers during office hours, he teaches statistics in a very approachable way. He goes over all the tests and problem sets in class and has multiple review sessions to make sure you do well. It's not hard to get an A- if you put in the work

Professor Raviv really knows his statistics and teaches in a very organized way. If you don't put in the effort, show up to all his lectures, and try your best on the problem sets, you're going to find the class difficult. But he is very clear about expectations and gives you practice tests + solutions
Prof Raviv is the man. Stats is hard but he is very fair, heavy curve and give you good prep. Will sit in office hours until you get it. Good sense of humor too and cares about students.

Worst, worst, worst professor at the 5Cs. He really doesn't know what is teaching. Content is way harder than parallel classes. His horrible accent makes his class not understandable at all. More importantly, he doesn't know what is pace. He goes really fast with his super hard content, no one is motivated to learn. Avoid him!

Professor Raviv is very nice and willing to help. With that being said, his class is very confusing and the lectures do not do much for you. You basically learn through doing the problem sets. He gives you practice midterms, and there are no surprises. You know exactly what kind of problems will be on the exams. Very big curve, but tough class.

Has a thick accent which is tough to understand and doesn't really explain anything. In class, he really just gives you equations and then uses them without explaining what they mean so conceptually you have no idea what you're doing

Really helpful and kind outside of class. He tells you that the exams have no surprises and they really don't. If you clearly know all the material on practice midterms you will do fine on the actual exam
Not the most interesting, but it is statistics. Really easy to talk to outside of class
boring ....hard to understand....circular in his explanations...
Very hard to understand because of his thick accent. But if you have no choice but to take his class what can you do.

Raviv is a great teacher. He is willing to go over any concepts or work you don't understand. His homework can be difficult but that is help you learn and prepare you for tests. He was also a great teacher for Game Theory.
He's very hard to understand, probably because of his accent. The class material is very interesting though.
Outstanding prof.  Very entertaining.  Quite the jokester.  If you are good at math you will do great.

Raviv is great. He has been one of my favorite professors here. He tells you the first day, if you are willing to work hard in this class, then you will do well. It's true. He's very friendly and helpful. I recommend!

Raviv is awesome. Among the easiest classes I have ever taken. The exams are pretty much the same as the practice exams. Anyone who thinks Raviv is difficult is just really bad at math/lazy. Oh yeah, each exam has a generous curve too. If you put in any effort whatsoever you will get at least a B. Funny guy and helpful outside of class. Take Raviv.

He is without a doubt the hardest professor I have ever had to deal with. He gives impossibly difficult homework assignments and his tests are on subjects not covered in class. Personally, however, he is a very nice and reasonable man who will not fail you if you put in the effort
literally the hardest class i have taken in my life. you actually want to cry after the test. TAKE RAVIV IF YOU WANT THE WORST FEELING YOU HAVE EVER FELT IN YOUR LIFE!!!!

as many have said before, raviv is boring. however, his powerpoint notes are quite helpful and he explains material pretty well. his problem sets are long and difficult, but he grades them very easily. his midterms and final are really hard, but he curves to a B so it's not too bad. very intense guy, but he's nice if you get to know him.
Professor Raviv was a great teacher. Enthusiastic about helping students, willing to spend his time to help the students that would approach him and show them ability in his field

prof raviv is boring and goes through material very fast. however, his powerpoint notes are very helpful and he curves generously on exams. he's a really nice guy, although he can be intimidating because he's so intense. if you're a math person, this class is not hard. if you're math challenged, it may be difficult. but overall, raviv is great.

Professor Raviv is boring as hell.  He has powerpoint presentations for each class and they are posted online.  There is no reason to attend class.  Midterms are challenging but there is a generous curve.  He is a really cool guy but man his class is boring.

gl if you are stuck in this class.  I don't know how you are supposed to learn.  My friends in class taught me.  Hard hard struggle to pull a B.  You gotta know the stuff he gives examples for super well.  His lectures are very poor and so hard to follow / stay tuned.  Very very willing to help, but his explanations were circular and not helpful

Wonderful professor, hard material. Thick Israeli accent, hard to understand. Lots of powerpoints, lectures will get dry. I learned most of the class from the books. Adores his students. Very willing to help us out. Walked us thru problem sets over lunch. One of the profs that I went to a small lib arts school for.

Very interested in his students learning.  Practices lectures to himself in his office! (haha)  Not good at keeping you updated on your score.  TOUGH EXAMS.  Sweet guy, very thick accent.  His lectures are very difficult to understant, but he provides thorough powerpoints.
An awesome guy and a good teacher.  Focuses on you learning and understanding rather than just memorizing formulas.  Keil or Raviv are the best two stats profesors.

Hard to understand because of his accent. Uses a lot of power point. Lectures are dry. He puts in a lot of effort but needs more experience. Tries his hardest to help you out. Tests are mostly reasonable but he puts some tricky problems in. Problem sets can be really hard at times.
A really nice guy!
Professor Sinha is great! If you want to be intellectually challenged, take her class. Otherwise, it can be hard...

She is honestly a brilliant professor! Ask her about anything from history to politics to philosophy and she will have an answer. She is also super helpful, but only if you are willing to work for it. Go to her office hours and ask her specifics about your essays and how you can improve.

The most disorganized class I have ever taken. Lectures are boring and unclear. Assignments are scattered and odd. Expect to do a lot of work for her, that will not necessarily further your understanding of the subject matter in question, and will seem random and peculiar.

Sinha is a professor who cares about her students and takes the time to get to know people on an individual level. I took Comparing Social Movements and really enjoyed it. The class covers a lot of material,  is very engaging and encourages participation. She is a no BS professor, so do the reading and be ready to participate. Would recommend.

Professor Sinha is fantastic. She knows what she is doing and is an extremely knowledgeable scholar and professor. She is always there for you and you definitely won't get as much out of the class if you don't go to office hours. I would recommend her for GOV60 and any upper level GOVIR class!

Professor Sinha's Comparing Social Movements class was awesome. She tries to give a wide breadth of different movements, and works with you really in depth to talk about exactly which movement you want to do for your huge research paper at the end of the semester. She is really knowledgeable about IR and government and is great to just talk to!

Professor Sinha is an incredible professor! I would highly recommend taking her GOV60 course. I took this course freshmen year and it definitely prepared me for the rigor and expectations of other Gov courses at CMC. Sinha is a great lecturer and actively encourages class participation. She is extremely helpful in office hours! Highly recommend!

Professor Sinha is by far one of the top three professors I have ever had. She cares so much for her students' success that she will do anything in her power to help them. Her classes are very interactive, and she allows students to lead class discussions.

Professor Sinha is by far among the top three professors I have ever had in my life. She cares about her students' development, and she will do anything to help them succeed. She is not just a professor; she is an advocate for her students.

The lectures are extremely unorganized and confusing, and very dry. Very little participation. No real structure. Don't discuss most of the readings and they are extremely long and time consuming. Not a great class and honestly would not want to take another class with her. She is a nice lady however. Very boring.
The lectures are not clear. The class has no structure and we do not talk about most of the readings. Try to avoid taking her if you can. 10-15 page research paper as final

The material was interesting, but her teaching ruined the course. She penalises those students who participates, dodges questions she can't answer (which happens a lot), and generally sucks the fun out of the subject.

I definitely recommend taking Aseema's GOVT060 class! She is a sweet and bright lady. She is always willing to help and she never forces you to participate in class, though she has room for class participation (i.e. its not all lecture). Her tests are not hard - she focuses on important concepts not trivial details.

Professor Bjornlie's class appears difficult at first, however, his Hist054 Class, Bread and Circuses, was an excellent choice for my history prereq. The class syllabus includes a lot of reading however it is not necessary to complete the majority of it in its entirety. I highly recommend that you take in-depth notes on your computer for this class

Professor Bjornlie is extremely knowledgeable eloquent, and passionate about History. Class is reading heavy and classes are loosely structured lectures/ discussions. It's easy to nod off but it is in your best interest to take diligent notes. Highly recommend going to office hours. If you are willing to work hard and ask for help, you will do well

Bjornlie's FHS class is hard. It is not an easy class. You'll have to read tons of books, but they are interesting and the Prof. makes the books and class discussions truly interesting. If you like tales of heroes or ancient stories or Lord of the Rings, this will be the best class you'll ever take.
I really enjoyed this class. I found lectures and discussions engaging. It was a fair amount of reading but pretty mangeable for a history class.

If you like Roman and Late Antique History there is no Professor better than Prof Bjornlie. He is the most passionate professor that I have met and although his jokes can be corny they are still funny. If you need help all you need to do is ask. Not an easy professor but he is fair and the work is always manageable.

Prof Bjornlie is really enthusiastic about the material and his enthusiasm is infectious. The readings and lectures (more so the lectures) are super interesting. Don't procrastinate on the papers. They're graded fairly and if you BS he will definitely catch you, and then your grade will tank. But don't let the workload scare you; he's the man!

You can totally tell that he is passionate about Ancient history! I would, however, not recommend him for an FHS professor.  Discussions became lectures where he would just ramble on for what seemed like hours. He assigned a lot of reading- so much so that none of us could ever complete the HW. Essays prompts were way too confusing.

Professor Bjornlie is one of my favorite professors, whether he is teaching a seminar or a lecture-based course. He is filled with an unending knowledge of Rome and Late Antiquity that includes not only a familiarity with primary sources and archaeological excavations, but also academic literature. Expect a lot of (rewarding) reading.

Professor Bjornlie brings everything Roman to life. He thinks about the past in a way that I've never seen before. The material is super interesting. There is a LOT of reading, but it's worth it in the end.
Excellent professor. Willing to help and always available. Clearly enjoys the material, and his affability is infectious.
Great teacher. KNOWS Roman history like no-one else. Class can get a little boring, but he's an awesome professor, super nice, and really knows his stuff. Took him for a GE and had a great time

Great professor! Super knowledgeable and very helpful!! Really gets you interested in Rome. Expects a lot from his students in papers, but not a difficult grader at all. Loved all 3 classes I took with him :)

The class was really interesting even though it was subject matter I'd never been interested in before. Assigns a LOT of reading, but you can probably get away with skimming it since he mostly focuses on the big picture. Be warned, procrastinating in this class can be dangerous - the final paper is due the same day as the final.

This professor works hard to teach great history.  One of the best lecturers around, every class day is like listening to a story.  The reading is pretty challenging, but he understands if you need an extension and will write rec letters as needed.  Great professor overall!!

Bjornlie really wants to see students succeed. Wonderful in office hours. At least skim all of the readings because he will call on you even if your hand isn't raised. Generally really fun and interesting topics. Shows the show Rome sometimes too!

Overall a great classroom experience. While lectures were a little boring (depending on subject content) he is a helpful prof who general wants his students to invest themselves in the subject matter. Be prepared to read a lot but if you forget listen in class. He is one of the most knowledgeable people I know.

Nice guy, wants to help his students, but tends to assign a lot of reading - know how to scan. Class is a good balance btw discussion and lecture - he has a great amt of background knowledge that supplements readings well. Essays, when graded, were fairly easy in my experience, but that was probably because this was an entry-level writing class.

Bjornlie is such a nice guy. He goes out of his way to help you with anything, and really cares about his students. He assigns tons of reading, all of which is good, but you will be graded on some of it. Papers are seldom, but graded fairly hard

Excellent professor. Very engaging and he know's his material extremely well. He is a fair grader and he will go above and beyond to work with you in office hours. Not very many graded assignments, but quite a bit of reading.

I have taken several classes with Prof. Bjornlie and I really love his teaching style. A good combination of lecture and discussion. You must come prepared to class and put thought into your papers. Not all of his classes have tests.

Professor Moffett was my favorite teacher this semester. I learned so much in his class, the assignments were relevant and fun. Would 100% take his class again, would recommend all freshmen to take this given the chance. He is also very casually funny which always makes class interesting. A great person overall.
Class discussions on readings are engaging if you get involved. Really helps to improve your writing, if you put the work in. Interesting and varied prompts for papers.

Amazing fiction writing professor who helped me significantly improve my own work. He was completely unpretentious and collaborative during our workshops, and made suggestions to my writing as a peer rather than an instructor, which was amazing because he is a successful and established writer himself.

Moffett is amazing. His class is not only interesting, but he really taught me to be a better writer this semester. The reading was usually way overkill, and he does grade pretty hard but not unreasonably. The class is heavily weighed on participation, which is fine bcuz the class discussions are usually interesting. Overall, would 100% recommend.

Really good guy and a great person to just talk to. He's a really caring person too, and will reward you if you're showing growth in your writings. Definitely not an easy "A" class, but if you put in the work, it's possible! He helps you bring out your creativity and immerses you in this seemingly mundane, yet intricate and vastly interesting topic
Love this professor. You definitely have to possess some skill in writing ignorer to get a good grade, but Moffett is definitely willing to help you get better if you make the effort and ask.

Respected and published professor who knows what he's doing. Course work for FWS Post Apocalyptic Narratives was not bad. Two major papers, three short responses, one short story. Do not expect to get better at writing unless you put in the work by meeting with him at office hours. Need to be a good writer to get a grade. Not much writing help

Rajczi is a king. He will be one of those people I will be thinking about for the rest of my life. His classes were very engaging, discussion/thinking oriented. He uses an active learning method that I loved and found effective. I can't say enough good things about this class. Reasonable but still challenges his students, this class is a gem.

Very accessible outside of class and will talk to you about the material if you have any questions about it. That being said, it's very hard to nail down what it is exactly he wants from students (which is strange, because he's simultaneously very critical). This makes a lot of his grading feel somewhat arbitrary.

Rajczi is an awesome professor and an awesome guy. He's deeply empathetic for student concerns and is always willing to take feedback. When he sees a student idea, he takes the time to consider if the student has noticed something he hasn't and will change his ideas accordingly. The primer is a godsend and will 100% boost your grade in the class

Best class I've taken at CMC. Convinced me to become a Phil major. The professor explains the material in a very organized and methodical way that helps you understand it entirely, even though the subject is difficult. Class is mostly discussion and activity based which made it really fun. Especially great for someone who's never taken phil before.

I really enjoyed Professor Rajzci's class. He cares about student input. The essays were challenging but he is very available outside of class and is very willing to provide a ton of feedback to help students improve. Professor Rajzci is enthusiastic, caring, and helpful. I recommend taking his class, especially if you need the GE.

This is simply not the guy you want if you actually care about the broader implications of the subject. He is inept to think beyond his narrow construction of ethics and morality which is HEAVILY centered in an exhausting CMC, Westernized style of learning and global understanding. Sooo disappointing given the subject of the class (warfare ethics)

Rajczi is worth taking. Class discussion is well-led for the most part, subject matter is interesting, and the man is cuttingly bright. He can have a restrained temper if people get too unruly. PAPERS REALLY TAKE YOU TO TASK: you have to prepare them well in advance and get feedback in office hours to do well, as he grades them toughly.

Rajczi is an awesome choice for a philosophy prof. Since you're probably going to need to take at least one philosophy class in college, and every class you take is going to have a huge lecture component, you should choose the one that's most interesting in class, and that's definitely Rajczi. Whenever you get lost, his office hours are helpful.

Someone told me Rajczi was the "philosophy Buddha," and I can't disagree. His knowledge of his topic is impressive, but he really shines in how he relates to his students inside and outside of class. Discussions are engaging and provoking, like the readings. Outside of class, he organizes events like hikes and jam sessions to know his students.

He is hands down my favorite professor. I've taken three classes with him, soon to be four. He makes difficult material easy to understand and is always available to speak in office hours. He's also really funny! And he truly cares about the well being of his students, so he doesn't give too much homework. Also asks for feedback. Easy B, hard A.
Professor Rajczi almost turned me into a Philosophy major. His class is really interesting and looks at modern day philosophical issues. He's a tough grader but go to office hours!
Smart, energetic, he really understands his subject matter and has a passion for teaching it.

Best professor at CMC. Super funny. Keeps class really interesting. The subject matter is great. He's reasonable and assigns the perfect amount of reading. Best feedback on papers I've ever received. Made me consider majoring in philosophy. People say he can be a bit condescending but he really isn't. Take his class!!!! You won't regret it.

I actually really liked this class and I think he genuinely made me a smarter person. The workload isn't bad- you write a one page paper each class but it's usually just a reflection and he doesn't want you to take more than 30 mins on it. Plus 3-4 major papers. Taught me a lot. And go to class to discuss or else you won't get participation points!
Worst class at CMC. Rajczi is VERY patronizing and controlling. Hated every minute of it.

Favorite course and professor by far this semester! He chooses modern and stimulating topics like religion, robots, and happiness. He engages with students and facilitates class discussion. He is a hard grader, but he gives tons of feedback and he doesn't give too much homework. Highly recommended!

Really enjoyed his class, Political Phil Honors. Super interesting class, interesting prof too! Learned how to write really good phil papers.  Hard grader, tough curve.  Don't take his class if you won't attend, he can be nit picky--with things other than attendance too.

I took his political philosophy class, which was really interesting. It is a good foundation for thinking and writing in a rational way, and actually helped me with my papers for other classes. The class is based on two papers, so if that will stress you out, don't take the class. Also, the grading can seem sort of arbitrary and he's a hard grader.

Professor Rajczi's class was filled with ungraded busywork which you were penalized for not doing and boring discussions over pointless minutia.  My least favorite class I've ever taken at CMC or even in high school.  I learned nothing about philosophy.

His class is the best I have taken at CMC. He is thought provoking and wants his students to explore the issues raised and to further understand their own beliefs and opinions. He produces good philosophers.

Don't take his classes.  He gets stuck on a few arguments and doesn't even really cover them that well.  Also an insane grader.  He says no page limit, but really he wants 20 or more double spaced.  You won't benefit and most likely it'll hurt your GPA.

Hilarious guy and keeps class interesting.  Facilitated and directed discussions well and allowed us to turn in our paper a second time to get a higher grade.  Plans activities outside of class like jug band night at his house :)

This professor changed the way I think about learning for the better. The skills you learn in his class will transfer over to all other disciplines. He is extremely helpful outside of class and genuinely cares about the learning experience for the student. Listen to him carefully, he is very wise and candid.
Not a lot of busy work, but a lot of effort is expected from students. You probably will get a lower grade than you usually do, but the class will be a deep learning experience.
He is a really good professor!  He is engaging in class and helpful outside of class.  Discussions are really good.  many papers, but you learn a lot.
Rajczi is good but there is frequent written work and readings, but they keep you on task.  his class discussions are good but sometimes he can be unclear what he wants in assignments.
Very good class.

Racjzi is a great guy and very funny. He makes his classes interesting.  Not challenging enough yet, but his assignments will make you think. Go to office hours with him!  He's very accessible (even gives you his home phone number).

This guy is really accessible - make sure to take advantage of the fact that he invites students to lunch and the Ath. He may seem intimidating and a difficult grader at first, he's a really caring and helpful guy who goes the extra mile to help motivated students.

He was pretty easy.  I found him pretty fair in his expectations (I never read anything after the first two weeks and got B's on my papers), but I do feel that he was sort of cold; he made me feel pretty uncomfortable overall whenever I answered questions.  He's not too bad, though.

Tough, tough, tough grader and class. Really makes you work for that A, requires significant participation, and the exams are very difficult (hardest I've had at CMC). But you learn a TON. If you really want to understand cog psych I would absolutely take her class. I do not recommend this class as a GE unless you want a really challenging GE class

She is an incredibly difficult professor, but teaches very well. I spent on average 1-2 hours in her office every single week for the last half of the semester and barely got an A in the class. Go to office hours if you want to do well. All in all, I learned more than I've learned in any other class and acquired an amazing foundation in the course.

I thoroughly enjoyed Professor Umanath's cognitive psychology class. She is super enthusiastic about the subject and makes class interesting and fun. Her tests make up a majority of your grade, and she does expect a lot out of her students, but overall the class is engaging and useful. Get ready to work, and don't shy away from participating.

The material of the cognitive class is interesting and the class is organised. But her grading is unnecessarily hard, and all midterms are cummulative. I would not recommend to take this as a GE, altough it does not require intro to psych.

It's the worst class you can ever take, professor is horrible, she dosen't care and will fail you she demands a lot but dose',t give in a lot, talks in class, but no point because everything is partial and you are expected to do everything from home

Taking Umanath was a horrible experience. For full participation credit u have to speak at least 3 times a class, in addition to posting 3 discussion questions and 1 discussion response each night. +if you don't say exactly what she wants to hear, u don't get full credit. & despite being a psych, her discussions/acitivities were SUPER triggering

I love Professor Umanath. Took her autobiographical memory class and she is top of the top. She knows her stuff and is so passionate about it. Definitely a hard grader but if you are more interested in learning more about memory and psych, her class is the one to take. I found my interest in psych through taking her class so I highly recommend it
Dr. Umanath is very passionate about autobiographical memory! She can be tough in class, but is awesome to get to know!
Professor Umanath is awesome! great lecturer and so much fun to talk to outside of class!

Professor Taw is the smartest human I have ever met. She is an absolutely brilliant prof, and is excited to work with you on class content and assigned papers. The final term paper was tough, but she gave guidance and helped edit before it was due. You will work for it in this class - tough but incredibly interesting. She made me an IR major!

Taw is a real gem, & I recommend this class (War) to everyone. You will read a sh*t ton of books, & write so many papers, but I have never taken a more rewarding class. And a bit about Taw: she is SO intelligent & brings so much to discussions without being overbearing; she is sweet but tough; she gives a lot of help at her office hours. Love her!

Prof. Taw's classes will make you work for your grade, but it's so worth it. This class had a ton of opportunities for independent research, so you come out of the class with a way deeper understanding of the material than you might get from a lecture. Prof. Taw is the best, 100% would take more classes with her.

Professor Taw is what I came to CMC for. She's an incredibly knowledgeable professor, which sometimes leads her to lecture quite quickly, but I've learned an insane amount from her. She is one of the main reasons I decided to stay in the IR major. She's a tough grader, but if you go to office hours, it's very manageable. 100% would recommend!

Took two of her classes in one semester and it was brutal. Probably some of the most work I have done in a Government class. But I learned a lot and she does genuinely care about the quality of her class and her students. Take her class! Just know your gonna have to earn it.

Professor Taw is a life-changing professor. She is kind, brilliant and funny. Her class develops you as a student and as a person. She transforms you into a serious thinker, informed debater, and convincing writer. She demands a lot of work and her class shouldn't be taken lightly, but having her as a prof is extremely rewarding in many ways.

Professor Taw is truly an incredible professor, whose teaching style is best described as "tough love." She is equal parts caring and rough toward students, with her highest goal being student success.

Absolutely don't recommend taking 70h over 70... not much gained and 70h is significantly more difficult with much higher expectations.  Taw can be interesting & is very knowledgeable.  One frustration for me was that lectures simply rehashed readings which felt like a waste of time.  Very opinionated - always agree w/ her/write what she wants!

Taw is so incredibly knowledgable about everything govir related. She is willing to help in every area, whether it comes to understanding a difficult topic, or writing a paper. She assigns a TON of reading, and you pretty much have to do it in order to participate (which is 35% of your grade, and she really grades it). SUPER cool prof.
Most helpful professor ever! She will go out of her way to work through papers with you and help you get a good grade!

She does not give tricky tests. If you study you will do well. The papers need to be clean, academic, and well-edited. She speaks very quickly and is extremely knowledgeable. I learned alot in this class. Very good intro to IR (I did not take the honors gov70 just regular.)
Extremely hard professor!! Favors certain students in class and tries too hard to be cool. By far, she is the worst prof in the IR department...

I didn't like this class: grading on papers was very arbitrary and it is true- she doesn't like to admit when she is wrong and she can be very condescending at times, forgetting to be constructively critical.
Taw is one of my favorite profs ever. She is extremely knowledgeable and loves what she does. Our group discussions were great. Reading is necessary but not too long. Highly recommended prof.
She's extremely approachable and willing to help you out. She focuses a bit more on lecture than I would prefer, but always willing to take comments.

She's amazing! She is very knowledgeable. I took her for gov 20 where she tends to lecture a lot, but i enjoyed it. She is always available outside of class and although instructions can be vague if you go to her at office hourse she is very helpful. definitely take her!

Fantastic prof, took her Honors Intro to IR, she's nice, helpful, and so smart and knowledgeable.  Her grading is fair without being too difficult and she is always available for help outside of class.

Nice lady, awful professor. Gives middle-school level assignments and changes her expectations constantly, so can never give her what she wants. Grading is random and absurd. Won't admit when she's wrong. All you learn about is the levels of analysis- security studies was like an awful intro to IR class. Don't take!
Really nice teacher with lots of knowledge about Int'l politics.  She is suuuper nice too!
She is absolutely amazing! She is knows SO much, and she is willing to help you out in anyway possible. She always has answers to ALL your questions, and she really just wants you to learn.

Prof. Lobis is incredibly knowledgeable in his field, and his discussion input and essay feedback reflect that. FWS010 (Shakespeare and Otherness) was difficult but a real gem if you enjoy reading and studying Shakespeare. He isn't necessarily a tough grader, but it is difficult to get in the A range for an essay.

Professor Lobis is the best Professor Ive had at CMC. Hes brilliant and speaks so precisely it inspires you to choose words more carefully. Hes a very reasonable grader (but takes a while to get your papers back). Im not a lit major and I would highly recommend LIT 68 to anyone. He brings alive the brilliance of Shakespeare!

Very witty professor who made me enjoy Shakespeare, something I never thought I would enjoy reading and learning about. The class atmosphere is very mellow and discussion based. Definitely one of the better classes I've taken at CMC.

Professor Lobis is delightfully sassy and articulate (his speaking is more precise than most writing). You do need to participate, but he's very forgiving if you make dumb comments during discussion. Moderately tough grader for papers imo, non-literature majors may have a tough time. Don't take Brit lit for a GE, take Shakespeare or Milton with him

Had him for Milton and it is by far my best class this semester!! He's very smart and discussions are always interesting and lively, and he has a good sense of humor. I really didn't expect to like this class but I grew to love it. He is also super accessible and takes time to meet with everyone about papers.
One of the best professors at CMC. Hard, but if you go to this college you shouldn't complain. Fair, interesting, kind, engaging. Also a great guy.

FWS (Magic, Science, and Literature) felt exactly like AP English.  Every class consisted of only class discussion, which was quite interesting.  Prof Lobis knows what he is teaching.  He is GREAT for people who like literature/writing.  However, if you are not a strong writer in literary criticism, his papers are hard to do well on.

Professor Lobis is an incredible seminar leader. He takes the class dive deeply into the material and discover aspects and beautiful nuances which hardly any of us could even think about. One downside: He is willing to help you with the essay's introduction and skeleton, but insists on the fairness not to help you go through the essay in details.
Good guy, extremely knowledgeable on the subject (John Milton).  If his grading wasn't easy, it was at least reasonable.  Very accessible.

Lobis is possible the biggest slayer out there, in a good way ofcourse. Taking his class really popped my bubble and thrust me into world of college writing. It is a hard class but his lectures are inclusive and interesting if you're willing to put in the required work. Go to his office hours; listen to what he has to say about your writing!
I'm in love with him. I literally worship this god of a man. Lobis is an unstoppable sass master, and you should consider it an honor if you have the chance to be slayed by Slobis.

Lobis is fantastic. Very helpful in office hours and an excellent discussion-driver in class. He's humorous and insightful and knows how to keep people interested. Really wish I'd taken more courses with him! Also very helpful as far as help with papers.

Professor Lobis is a very helpful professor. He responds to emails very promptly. His class can be kind of boring but his friendliness makes up for it. He isn't too difficult of a grader. I would definitely take another class from him.
Professor Lobis is incredible. You have to take his class! He is very engaging and helpful. He truly cares about all of his students. SEEK HIM OUT AT TEA!

Great professor--Very Engaging and helpful during office hours.  The reading selection is excellent, and the work load is very manageable.  Your writing is almost guaranteed to improve during the course.
Excellent professor.  Challenging yet extremely helpful if you choose to go in and see him.

Great prof! I've taken two classes with him, (Lit 10, Shakespeare's Comedies) and I feel like my writing has improved drastically. He's really nice, and also very helpful if you go to his office hours to talk about essays etc.

Really great professor, excellent at leading class discussion.  Though a little more tough on grading than most professors, if you take his comments to heart, you will see an improvement in your grades.

Awesome prof in class - one of the most intelligent at CMC.  The workload in Shakespeare was very realistic and graded fairly.  The final exam, on the other hand, was TOUGH.  The passage ID was from the entirety of the syllabus (8 plays) and the IDs were 2 lines long.  Overall, a great learning experience since he was such a great discussion leader

Prof Lobis is one of the best profs at CMC! He is extremely enthusiastic and can make even the most boring literature exciting to read and discuss-every class period flies by! He is also very helpful outside the classroom and provides many opportunities to meet with him to discuss your papers. Take any of Lobis' classes you can, he's the best!
He's a lot more helpful than the other professors teaching this class. He is very understanding and kind. If the class is struggling he gives lectures which are very helpful.

Professor Mioy is AMAZING! He is such a caring person and goes above and beyond to help if you are having a hard time. He has a website with amazing practice problems and extra resources that even my friends that weren't in his class used. He is supper funny too! I hope he teaches p chem in the future! (He doesnt grade tests like reviews said)

Chem14 itself is extremely rigorous and time-consuming, but Professor Huyhn does an exceptional job of explaining the concepts in multiple different ways. He teaches in a way that does not exclude or discourage you if you do not have previous chem experience. Huyhn is very real with his students- Brilliant and caring teacher.
