Prow Huynh is great but chem14 in Keck is horrible especially with the flipped classroom curriculum. Lectures are prerecorded by like 5 different professors and during class you only work and worksheets. I went to class a total of 5 times per entire semester I think

Contradicts himself in lecture, does not use book and has his own website with explanations. Exams are impossibly graded. He docks points for sig figs in scratch work, expects you to read provide information that is not asked for in the question. The homework sets are easy though.

Professor Valencia is perhaps the best Portuguese teacher at the 5C! His class is fairly easy and there is not too much homework. He is super supportive to students who do not have any background in Portuguese and is really helpful outside of class.
I loved this class and Norman so much! Participation is super easy and the workload is super manageable making it a really fun class.

Valencia was an awesome professor! He really just wants students to learn and appreciate the Spanish language so he will do whatever he can to help. He gives tons of feedback on essays and allows you to submit corrections to increase your grade. Definitely take him!

Its so clear that hes passionate about his subject and its absolutely infectious! I loved the discussions in this class and his knowledge. I also really recommend going to his office hours! Homework is very manageable and class is really fun! I considered somehow adding literature to my major after this class. He is amazing!
Professor Warner is absolutely amazing and is one of the most inspiring professors I've ever had. His feedback in super helpful and his lectures are always fun!

Professor Warner is the most accommodating, inspiring and caring professor I have ever had. He is not an easy grader, but if you are willing to meet with him outside of class and put in the work, your writing will improve a lot. He delivers long lectures but they are engaging and he is always encouraging class participation.
Prof. Warner gives really good feedback and is super accessible after class. I took his online FWS class and it improved my writing a lot. A solid choice for FWS for sure!

Professor Warner is a phenomenal professor. He is extremely kind and offers a lot of support. He has helped me a lot with my writing and once he gets to know you he makes it his personal project to help you improve. His classes are fascinating: even if you don't like reading you will learn a lot. He replies to emails and gives feedback instantly.

Professor Warner is the BEST! While he is a tough grader, I learned the most about writing techniques and reading styles. He gives detailed & amazingly helpful feedback on papers and will 100% greatly improve you as a writer. The challenge in his class was definitely worth it for the amount I learned. He shares his passion for literature every day!

Very knowledgeable. It is possible to get an A, but you must work for it. He always opens up extra office hours and is very helpful. He is always available for help, so if you are struggling he will most definitely help you and make you a stronger writer. Very often goes off task and never really completes all the tasks on the syllabus as it says.

If you want to become a better writer, take Prof. Warner. His feedback can feel nit-picky, but it is always specific and helpful. He invests time in his students. Class was a mixture of lecture and discussion with some really great handouts.

Professor Warner makes every penny of your tuition worth it! His classes are not easy, but if you go to him for assistance, he is very helpful. If you want to learn how to write, take this course. One of the best professors at CMC.

Warner is tough and very critical of writing at the sentence level. Some might call him nitpicky, but I think it does help improve your writing. He's very accessible outside of class and cares a lot about his students. Old and conservative, gets very excited about his stuff. The Russian Novels class is in my top 10 favorite classes of all time.

Best teacher I have ever had!!! Interesting and wise lectures, excellent comments and advice on your writing and a great attitude. He is so committed to his students and would talk with me on the phone on the weekend. I became a great writer after taking his class. Love him!

Professor Warner is amazing! He is the only person who has ever made me excited about a sentence (and will be the last). He's available for office hours, email, and even allows calls on the weekend. If you put in the work, your writing with drastically improve. Honestly, one of the best profs! Sometimes, he isn't good at managing class time though.

Professor Warner will make you a good writer. His grading is tough and he will notice the smallest of mistakes, but it's to help you improve your writing. He will give you feedback longer than your essay and heavily encourages you to see him outside of class- DO IT.

He goes out of his way to make the subject interesting and make himself available outside of class. You really have to work for an A, but when you do, you learn a lot. He'll make you a better reader/writer. His feedback is sometimes longer than your entire essay, and it's because he truly cares about helping his students learn.
Fantastic prof.  He was incredibly patient, passionate, and engaging throughout the whole semester.  Highly recommend him+his cooking analogies are the best.

He is just amazing! The best professor I've ever met. Very passionate, always willing to help (great office hours), plus he has a good sense of humor. He makes you a great writer. I'd like to take his class every semester if I can!
Truly the most passionate teacher I've had. Take his romantic revolution class if you like to discuss and have a conversation instead of pure lecture.
A great professor who is always ready to help his students. He is very passionate about the material, but does have very high standards and a B+ is a good grade in his class.

i took his russian novel course and it is absolutely amazing. he is, first of all, an amazing professor. he is definitely not the type of professor you want if you are not interested in lit or plan on not putting in a lot of effort. he is the nicest prof i know and is so enthusiastic about russian literature you want to be that interested as well.

Warner is an amazing professor. Although he is a difficult grader (expect a B+ to be your highest grade), he definitely makes each class very entertaining, engaging, and fun. He is one of the most knowledgeable people I have ever met, and he is very open to new ideas during discussion. He is genuinely interested in his students' learning. Take him!

I LOVE WARNER! He is so engaging in discussions and lectures and makes literary theory which could be extremely boring actually really interesting!  He acts out authors accents like Freud and it's pretty funny.  He is ALWAYS willing to help you and discuss presentations and essay topics for hours in his office.  He is one of my favorite professors!

Warner is a great teacher! In highschool, I hated every lit class and every book we read, but he made the classes interesting.   He grades pretty hard on the essays but if you see to discuss your essay beforehand he will really help you.  My writing improved substantially because of this class.

Reasons why I LOVE Warner: 1)Engaging discussions. 2)Makes the discussions interesting and funny by acting out the characters with their accents.3)he makes you a brilliant writer. 4)The class is all getting B's and above - not too bad. 5) His enthusiasm for literature is adorable. 6)Very helpfull. 7)His teaching is inspirational. seriously.

Professor Warner is a captivating lecturer, very clear about the class and requirements, and really  makes it hard NOT to see him outside of class to help with your writing. He is indeed a tough grader but it's reasonably fair since he is upfront about raising the bar.

"Full of sound and fury, signifying nothing."  I was disappointed with his leadership class.  He claims to be a tough grader - but what that really means is 1 it isn't clear what he wants 2 the class is structured so it's hard to improve.  You only have one or two assignments of each type - so by the time you know what he wants, it's too late.

While I understand that Professor Warner is great in some of his other classes, he was only marginally good in Leadership in Lit. and Film. He didn't seem to understand it very well.  I think this is because leadership is his hobby, while the other classes that he teaches reflect his professional interests. Probably is good for other classes though

I asked my friends for an amazing professor from any department at the 5Cs and 5 people indedendently recommended him- I'll take his class again, no matter what the topic- you learn so much and he's so dynamic.
Absolutely brilliant. Expect to be challenged but don't go in expecting an A  - you probably won't get one. A totally worthwhile class.

I was Pitzer student but I decided to take one of his classes anyway. He was very demanding but it was worth it. His lectures were so compelling and thought provoking that I hated to miss. He once gave me an awesome write up of one of my assignments that I still have posted in my office today. I good grade from him means something. Smokn hot too!

Awesome man, great heart. Didn't always agree with the guy, though, but that's alright, he is the professor. He was my thesis reader and told it to me straight. I've never met a teacher more passionate about his/her subject. You definitely need to communic
The excitement he has for English is contagious.  I loved all his classes -- and he always remembered my name when I would see him on campus.  Impressive!
This man is brilliant and captivating. Rarely, if ever, have I encountered a better teacher. He's won a bunch of awards and published a really cool book. And umm... I kind of have a crush on him.
I only came to class to hear his thoughts.
No Comments
I took war in modern lit from Prof. Warner. It was the best course I took at CMC. He demands a student's absolute best.

He will give you a B- or B, if you are lucky, if you write a good paper but do not go see him about it. You will NOT get an A unless you go discuss your paper with him beforehand.  He an AMAZING lecturer.  He is captivating and BRILLIANT, but not the most fair grader.

The only way to get an A on a paper is to go out of your way and meet with him to discuss it.  He's very willing to make time to meet with you though.  The workload is pretty light, and the class is a lot of discussion, but again, meet with him for the A

He's so cool. He is very generous with tests and they are kinda easy if you know the material (he doesn't try to trick you). Doesn't answer emails which is annoying but always has office hours. I recommend

Professor Luck cares a lot about his students, but sometimes it just gets ridiculous. For instance, he agrees with basically anything that a student might say and then tries to steer them in a right direction, but that is just confusing. His lectures are mostly boring, but otherwise he is a good professor who genuinely tries to make Econ engaging.

Love prof luck!!! Cares about students and super clear, engaging lecturer. Participation is not graded but lecture style is a back and forth with students. Very accessible during office hours to ask questions or just chat. Wants to get to know his students! Progressive approach to grading provides ample extra credit, does not cap # of ppl w As

She is a horrible FWS professor. Instead of genuinely helping students improve their writing, she drills us on rigid essay structure and leaves no room for creativity. I felt like I had become a worse writer after her class. Class readings were interesting however, writing papers was absolutely miserable. Constantly felt discouraged in class!
Hard grader but easy to do well in the end.

She grades super tough and also forces students to write in support of things like the existence of patriarchy. I believe patriarchy does exist to an extent, but to force students to write a paper supporting the existence of it goes against my instincts of respect for other people's perspectives on the world. My classmates felt uncomfy about it....

I took Professor Gallagher's Post-Apocalyptic Humanity FWS course despite hearing negative things from other people. I actually really enjoyed the readings (one being a comic book) and thought that they all worked well together. Discussions were awkward since it was a small class and her grading is definitely very tough, but overall it wasn't bad.

Most painful class I've ever taken. Most end up with fine grades but the stress is not worth it. Gives horrible grades on early essays then better grades at the end to make you think you've become a better writer when you've probably gotten worse. Tells you your ideas are bad if they don't match hers. Her writing advice won't fly in any other class

Your grade is 40% weekly homework, which is easy to score high on. This cushions the grades for more difficult assignments like the final two essays (2000 words each). You should do well on the essays if you go to office hours and basically just reiterate what the text and the prof say. He's a super good prof so discussions were always interesting!

Great professor and interesting class. Readings can be a bit long but they are interesting and worth reading. There are reading responses which consist of about 10-12 sentences regarding the reading and they are due the day before your class at 2 pm which can be a bit inconvenient. Other than that great class!

Kind, genuine professor who gives plenty of opportunities for extra credit. Readings are contemporary and applicable to modern day society, which is especially handy considering "moral and political issues." Only drawback is he assigns reading responses for every class due in the middle of the day, the day before class- so it's fairly inconvenient

Prof. Frigault is super interesting and he made our 8am worth getting up for. Before each class, you have a 10-20 page reading and you answer 4 questions (2-3 sentences each) about what you found interesting + questions you have about the reading. The class is discussion-based so there are lots of opportunities to participate. Definitely recommend!

Love Professor Rentz! Such a sweet, caring professor. Very willing to meet you during office hours and accommodate you during the semester. A hard grader on the essays, but very generous with the rest of the assignments. Decent workload and is very manageable. Love the reading material and make class discussions very inclusive.

Love her! She's the sweetest prof and you can tell that she loves what she teaches. Her FWS class "Making Monsters" is similar to a high school literature class, but with more focus on writing skills. There's a reading before every class, and you have to submit 400 words every week.

Literally one of the most (if not THE most!!) kindest, caring professors at CMC. She makes sure classes and content are accessible and engaging to anyone, whether you're a medieval history fan or experiencing it for the first time. She made the online learning format enjoyable, which is a feat in itself.

Prof Rentz is such a lovely person. She truly cares about her students and reassesses the class workload based on student feedback. She can be flexible with deadlines, but provides enough structure to make sure we don't feel overwhelmed (especially in a Zoom setting). Her enthusiasm really rubs off on students and assignments are fun and doable
I think the class could have gone a little deeper and she could have connected a little better with us. Classroom environment felt a little fake and cold

Great prof! The first time Professor Rentz read Chaucer's Canterbury Tales in Middle English, all the students were completely mesmerized. She cares a lot for her students and is very accessible. Fascinating class, not too difficult if you pay attention! Will make you a better writer.

Took Monsters FWS. FWS is a course really nobody wants to take but you have to. That being said, she made the content interesting and I genuinely feel like my writing improved. Not too much workload (30-40 pages per class) and 3-4 medium length papers throughout the semester. She is super nice, understanding, and cares about you.

Took her for my FWS on Monsters. Great professor, she cares about you as a student as a person. She helped me improve my writing so much, and made my GE so much more interesting. Manageable workload, but be ready to write about a page for every class plus reading.

I love medieval lit because of Prof Rentz; she proposes nuanced, insightful interpretations of readings and thoughtfully considers contributions to the discussion. Assigned a reasonable amount of reading, a few essays, several brief quizzes. She is a feminist and applies these ideas to the chivalric romance in really interesting ways. Recommended!

Ellen Rentz is wonderful; she can occasionally get frustrated with students but the frustration clearly comes from a place of high expectations and respect and most of the time she is incredibly  kind. Reading is very manageable, grading on essays is not hard, and lectures are very fun, she makes long class periods pass very quickly. Take her class

Took her Shakespeare's Comedies class. We went through a play every two weeks or so, with a small amount of writing after each and a few bigger projects. She's a very sweet person, and a great professor for anyone, whether you're a Lit major or just trying to get through your GE requirement.

A very nice woman who's class was interesting at times, but was often dull. Her grading is harsh and wants her writing in a specific style. However, she is always available for help when you need her! She's better suited for an upper-level English class, rather than FWS. If you're a strong writer, take her.

She's a really invested professor and really helpful when it comes to writing. She cares about her students and picked good readings. I would definitely recommend her class. She values participation in discussion very highly

Chaucer. Took for a GE and it was actually a very enjoyable class. Loved Professor Rentz. She was a total sweetheart and was very helpful in office hours. Only two papers 5-7 pages, homework, and a research guide made up the grade. Not a whole lot of reading but that was counterbalanced by the fact it was all in middle english.
She was okay.  Definatly favors the brOwn nosers and hated most of the men in the class.  Feminist. Really helpful when writing essays though.

Rentz is an unbelievably wonderful professor. She's adorable, yes, but more importantly- she's a fantastic teacher. Sensible workload, fascinating and varied readings, lively class discussion. I want to be her when I grow up. It's a lit class but you also learn a ton of awesome medieval history. Super helpful outside of class,  funny, and sweet! A+
Rentz is extremely helpful and willing to meet with you whenever. She is enthusiastic about her work and sometimes brings candy!

Professor P-R is one of the best I had this semester! She's really inspiring and makes herself very available to students. I felt prioritized as a student in her class - she's responsive to emails and sets up appointments if necessary. The flipped classroom model is not ideal but she made it bearable & explained things well. Offers extra credit!!!

Purvis-Roberts is one of the most caring and overall nicest professors I have ever had. She genuinely wants to see her students succeed and is great in office hours. That being said, the tests are very difficult and are hard to study for. The work load is manageable and consists of problem sets every week, lab reports, and pre labs.

Purvis-Roberts is one of the nicest people in the world. Genuinely cares about all of her students and wants them to do well. Tests are difficult, but with a considerable amount of studying and focus you will do ok.

Very nice and clear throughout lectures. Her tests are challenging, but they are very fair. Didn't use textbook much apart from problem sets. As long as you take good notes and do lots of practice problems, you will be set! Go to her office hours! She is nice to just talk to and she brings her dogs in all the time!

She is VERY caring for her students! She cut homework, made 1 paper optional & let us have a notecard on exams. Reading the textbook is unnecessary bc all the exam questions are from lecture. The final paper was 18 pages & was TOUGH. Class was lecture-heavy but had many videos and breakout discussions that were engaging. Would 100% recommend her!

Do not take this course if you are a science major looking to fulfill a GE! This class is way too difficult for an intro level class, but Prof Doan is kind and will help you get the grade you want. The final is also optional. Would not recommend her for intro psych, but she would be great for an upper div course!

If you are a psych major and have time to study, take her! You will learn so much! But I would avoid if you are just taking for  GE. She works hard to make the class entertaining, but does expect you to read and study.

Fantastic professor, if you care to learn about psychology as a science! She works hard to get student feedback. Her lectures are pretty entertaining. Class is not the easiest, but meetings with her were extremely helpful.

Prof Stacey's intro to Psych class is clearly one of the best classes I have taken. Though she is a touch grader she expects her students to learn as much as possible. She expects her students to read particular chapters from the textbook before each class. I would recommend this class to all those people who are sincerely interested in learning

Her intro to psyc is not an easy class.  This course can teach you a lot if you put in the effort, but is too hard for an intro class.  The tests are tough, and it doesn't help that she sometimes gives inconsistent information.  She also constantly tests us on information that is covered in neither the review sheet nor the lecture.

Nothing about intro to psych in this class. Whole bunch of videos and her own research articles. Not what was required for intro to psych. Waste of time. She does not appreciate hard work. I should have taken other classes like my friends did.

All she wants to talk about are her research articles. That is NOT intro to psych dude! I needed intro to psych since I am a psych major and I learnt nothing in her class. She does not even give extra credit. Tough grader, tough tests. Run dude, run!

The class is quite difficult. As a Science student I would put the workload slightly below that of an into science course, however, it is also an amazingly immersive class where if you put the effort in, you can learn a lot. Prof. Doan is nothing short of inspirational and very knowledgeable. If you are premed, take this class, its worth it.

I think people don't like it because it's not an easy class. But if you put in the effort, you will learn a lot. She also curves the final grades! She uses video clips, to make class entertaining, and posts slides.
Easily one of the best professors at CMC. Great lectures, entertaining and knowledgeable! But it is not easy to get an A.

John is amazing! There are 3 individual presentations & 2 group debates projects all useful for the real world. He gives specific, helpful feedback! He is hard to reach outside class (seldomly at office hours and&rarely responded to emails). Most things are pretty straight forward so meeting outside of class isn't essential. 100% recommend!!

John Meany is a fantastic professor and a very kind man. He greatly helped me to improve my public speaking. This was an easy and fun half-credit that I would recommend to anyone and everyone. Public speaking is so important and useful, and he is a great professor to teach it.

Professor Meany is quite different from what his name suggests- he's one of the kindest, most nurturing professors I've encountered at CMC. His class required a lot of work, but his extensive feedback indubitably improved my skills involving professional communication. Amazing individual and extremely sharp professor.

Prof. Meany is one of the best professors 5C wide. He's up there with Dodds at Mudd. He gives amazing and useful feedback! I'm only half way through the class but i already know my speech skills have improved drastically. workload is 2-5 hours/week to prepare for your speech/presentation for that week. Class only meets once a week. 10/10 recommend
Intimidating at first, Prof. Meany wants everyone to participate and enjoy debate and will go the extra mile if you're willing to meet him halfway.
Brilliant, organized, incredibly hard-working.  He is one of academia's greatest minds.
He is amazing! From Tennessee Tech and the most amazing person in the world you should feel honored to be in class we travelled 1,600 miles to learn from him.
One of the best courses I've had at the 5Cs. My skills as a speaker improved tenfold, and now I hope to join the debate team. I strongly recommend this course to anybody.

He is absolutely crazy.  A very eccentric debate coach who will ramble on, literally for hours on any subject.  Amusing and interesting, he's a good coach, but when he gets into more advanced debate techniques he is almost unintelligible.
America's top three debate coaches include: Robert Trapp, Willamette University. Skip Rutledge, Point Loma Nazarene University. John Meany, the Claremont Colleges He is brilliant just fantastic.
Great guy and great speaker.

This class is tough but very worth it! All the projects are interesting and not just theory-based. You can keep doing the homework until you get everything right but you have to be willing to put in the time/effort. Mike encourages collaboration with peers and tutors. Lots of extra credit opportunities. Mike is incredibly knowledgeable and kind! :)

This course is difficult- don't get me wrong. But it would probably be easier than equivalent courses offered at HMC or Pomona. Our assignments helped build out our Github while being useful/practical. Mike clearly states that it will take 12 - 15 hours of work a week for an A- and that's pretty accurate. Put in the work and go to tutoring!!

Don't take CS40 as your Math GE. It is not an intro class, you need heavy coding knowledge. The increasingly harder quizzes and labs every week, the homework (1st was a multipage website, last is building a knockoff Twitter), and the attitude you'll receive from him for struggling, you might as well just take Calc 1.

Prof Izbicki is a great guy, and you'll learn a lot from his class. It's not an easy A, and you'll have to put in the hours to do well on quizzes and the assignments. He's very accessible outside of class, though, and actively encourages collaboration on everything. I'd definitely recommend this class; you'll take away a lot of great skills.

I like Mike. He is chill and the labs and homework are fun and useful. You might have a harder time if you never took CS before, but if you have some knowledge and you can teach yourself sometimes Mike is a great choice. He gives a lot of extra credit options. You build your GitHub portfolio during the course, which is very useful for future.

First portion of the semester was all theory and abstract CS/Math, while the second portion was all about implementation. The theory portion was very difficult for me, but grading was pretty much a guaranteed A, if you did the work. The 2nd half of the class gave me a lot of experience in actually coding all of the theory we learned earlier.

One of my favorite classes I have taken during all of College. Heavy emphasis on learning through projects and assignments. While the material was very difficult during lectures, the assignments were manageable and if you couldn't figure out the HW, he was always willing to give lots of help during office hours.
Can't teach

We had weekly homework assignments that were definitely manageable. His lectures are clear and concise and pretty easy to follow. He really tries to make sure you understand the material and makes himself very accessible in office hours to talk about your questions. He also makes sure that you know your questions are good and encourages them.

Disorganized lectures, midway through the semester after a midterm realized how little content I have learned from the course. Seems he is fine grading little, creating avg course content, and not pushing his students. Easy to do well, but angry about how little i took from a class that i heard was essential to CS

Classes are straight lecture - often boring. 3 noncumulative exams and 1 semester-long project. Study lecture notes for exams and also some textbook (it's about 90% class material, 10% textbook). I took this class thinking it would be an easy A, but I REALLY had to study HARD for the exams. Very nice man and accessible outside of class for help!

Org psych with Bowman was interesting and easy. Our grade was based on 3 exams, which sounds bad, but the exams were very straightforward. Mostly multiple choice with a couple of short answer questions that were always about theories we went over in class. If you read the textbook and take notes during lectures, this should be an easy A.
Bowman gave few tests his lectures were long. Group project lasted whole year. it was tedious, unclear grading. only took for major req.
His class is easy and he's somewhat helpful I suppose, but I found class to be super boring. The tests are definitely very easy though and he's a good guy.

Hilarious man! The material is fairly straightforward and clear, and he bases his tests mostly off of the notes from class, with a little bit from the book. 40 multiple choice, and 3 short answers. Basic intro course. Also there is a practical project with like 10 parts, due spaced out through the semester. never taken psych before, but loved this!

Sweet guy! Makes a lot of jokes during lecture and is very animated; makes sitting through class easy. Tests are more challenging than may be expected, but he prepares you rather well. I say go for it!
Class is basically all lecture, tests aren't too bad, he is clear and funny. Completely recommend taking him
Interesting teacher.  Hard MC portion of his tests, but other than that a good teacher!

Didnt give clear rubrics and instructions but graded hard with little explanation as to how to improve. Not accessible at all and class was very intimidating. I even asked for help because of unclear instructions and was denied. Did not feel supported to succeed in the class and is the reason I will likely not pursue Spanish further.

I loved this class so much! He is such an understanding and caring professor. The content of the class is super varied. A great mix of readings, movies, etc. Class discussion/participation is super important, so try to speak up!

As a freshman I was really worried about the essays, but he was very willing to give me feedback on my thesis before each due date. The syllabus is VERY clear on grading criteria and it's not hard to get an A if you visibly put in work. He will really like you if you're active in class discussion. He made me want to continue college spanish!
Prof. Velazco is great! One of my favorite Spanish classes--he really inspired me to study abroad in a Spanish speaking country. Super kind, really cares about his students.

Good Prof!  He's a sweet man who is really interested in what he teaches.  He has many "relaxful" days for the class and really just wants students to enjoy the class by discussing.  Really light workload

Velazco's Spanish 102 is my favorite class I have taken at CMC. Although he is not always open to students with views opposing his, he creates a lively discussion and includes many videos in his class. The essays and articles were great preparation for the big paper in the end. Take this class if you're interested in spanish beyond the textbook!

Prof. Velazco does not like people who miss his class.  Make sure you attend and get through the discussion.  Though boring sometimes, remember... it's only part of your day.  He is really open to student input and wants to create lively discussion, so open up!

Professor Velazco is awesome. He is a fun guy, and his class atmosphere is very relaxed. It's not a stressful class at all, but just make sure you contribute to the discussion. The work is VERY manageable. Take his class, you won't regret it!!!!

I am one of his Middlebury grad students. Sal is an outstanding instructor with really good connections in Lat. Am. film. Every week we have guest speakers from the Mex. film industry. Really approachable too!
I enjoyed the reading and discussion.

This guy is great!  he is really helpful too. the class is pretty easy, but really helpful.  you practice speaking and reading a good deal, and he makes it pretty fun because his standards arent too rigid.  easy to talk to. you watch a lot of movies so class time flies by.
That is so not true he is super funny
He thinks he is funny but hes not

Unhelpful and has a draconian attendance policy. His class is easy, I got an A without showing up much BUT then he knocked off a grade point for every absence after 3... I only passed because the language assistant was my friend and pulled hard for me.

A very sweet and interesting guy, like everyone said. I definately reccomend Latin American Cinema to all. It fills the Foreign Lit GE and is great if you want to work on your practical speaking skills rather than reading a ton. I'm a film major with just minimal Spanish and I got a ton out of it.
No Comments
I really like the class, very interesting reading material. I like the fact that we get to watch movie clips. Very interesting even for a native speaker!
I really enjoyed this class.  He makes things fun and rarely boring.  There is quite a lot of hw but it really helps to improve spanish skills especially with reading and writing.
such a funny little guy. Pretty cool projects and lots of movies
He made Spanish 101 interesting and fun, and I love that we got to see tons of movies and other media in the class.

I just didn't learn that much in this class and I don't think my peers did either. He's probably fine for intro and he's young so he'll get better as a teacher, but I generally wouldn't recommend him to others.
He is very open with helping students and providing support for papers and other assignments. 5 papers that aren't too difficult but lots of reading.

Even some of the best philosophy students that I know got A-s in her class, so if you want an easy A, find another prof. That said, you will definitely learn a lot and she is a terrific professor. She makes an effort to show that she cares about her students by being flexible with deadlines and taking the class out to dinner. Highly recommended.

Professor Johnson is easily the sharpest professor in the CMC philosophy department. At least in her upper level classes, she is a very tricky grader and will make it very difficult to get an A. If you're interested in the content she teaches, she's a must-have professor. If not, her grading criteria will seem arbitrary and excessively difficult.

Prof Johnson is amazing. She is very smart and knowledgeable in her area of expertise. She makes the class very interesting and fun. Grading criteria on papers are very clear but it's still not easy to get a good grade.

Be advised, while Professor Johnson is a great professor who is clearly knowledgeable about her stuff, she is an extremely tough grader. Grades seem somewhat arbitrary. However, you get what you put into the class, and on the whole she wants us to do well. Her humor is much appreciated. It's nice to be around a professor with a personality.

She's tough but very nice and she guides class discussions well so that they never feel stale while still giving everyone a chance to contribute. If you're shy in class, skip this one. But if you're committed to doing what it takes for a good grade, you will definitely learn a lot about ancient philosophy.

Lots of reading, good deal of writing, active participation in class is expected. This class will make you actively engage with and think about and debate the philosophical texts you're given. Excellent introduction to the field imo; it did feel like we were doing philosophy instead of merely reading it.

VERY RIGID. I wouldn't recommend unless you're well read in philosophy. She seems to have a one track mind for right and wrong answers, and is not open to philosophical interpretations. She also doesn't give much to explain or help with understanding and seems to push harder when a topic is difficult. She is not nurturing, and not very open.
Super fun and engaging professor. Makes every lecture super fun and interesting. But VERY HARD grader. You need to put in serious work to do well.

Easily one of the best professors across the 5C. Incredibly engaging professor who genuinely cares about your learning. Her classes are challenging, but you will completely understand every topic you cover. She is also tough grader, but it forces you to really focus on the clarity and precision of your language. Excellent professor!!

Lots of work in weekly readings & essays, but they are interesting. If you do the work and follow the instructions, class is not very difficult. Sometimes she uses difficult vocab, but judges essays only on strength of arguments (not writing style), which is very refreshing. Overall this is an interesting course for intro phil.

This class pushed me in the best way possible. The class is hard, but Prof. O helps you become an incredible writer. I always thought Philosophy was BS but she taught it in an incredibly accessible and methodical way. I 100% recommend this class to anyone (even for a GE)! She is a really tough grader but the class is so worth it.
Awesome. Take her class. She is very smart but also fun and loves her students. She brought us pizza multiple times. I want to take another philosophy class because of her.

Intro Phil. is A LOT of work, but it pays off. She makes you love philosophy, and really engages her students.  Looking back, I feel like I have learned so much in her class, from formulating arguments and ideas thoroughly and logically to breaking down complex arguments into pieces, to writing clearly and concisely.

The class is very intellectually challenging, yet extremely rewarding. Discussions were engaging, material was interesting, and lectures were clear. Participation is a large portion of the grade along with 3 papers. Go to office hours!! She is willing to go over tough readings or complex arguments. She challenges students to think for themselves.

Professor O's class literarily is the class that makes me fall in love with philosophy. She is very helpful and engaging. The structure of the lecture is extremely clear. The workload is much lighter than I expected. The average reading volume is about only ten pages. But it is true that you need to pay a lot of attention to it. TAKE HER CLASS!

Most amazing professor I have ever had. She is extremely helpful and will do anything she can to help you understand the material. She is very open minded in class discussions and the material is extremely interesting. If you have a chance to take a class with her, DO IT!

Professor O is the most amazing professor I have ever had.  She really knows her stuff, and she keeps class engaging and clear.  You learn about some of the most pressing philosophical issues in the history of philosophy, and she teaches you how to critically evaluate them.  This class will change your life, and Professor O is brilliant.

VERY Strict about attendence!  If you want a slacker class, this is not it.  The reading isn't too bad, but she challenges you to extrapolate farther than every expected, with a reading paper required for almost every class.  Prof. O keeps it dynamic in the classroom, too, with some of the best discussions I have ever had in my academic life.

Amazing! One of the best professors I've ever had. She inspired me to become a philosophy major. Prof. O. expects a lot from her students, but gives a lot in return. Don't take her ancient phil classes if you want to slack off.

Professor Obdrzalek is helpful and entertaining.  She has high standards for her students. In order to receive an "A" in the class, students should take their papers to her during office hours to get her feedback.  Her expectations are high but they are clear.  Without question, she goes above beyond the requirements of her job.

Professor O's Honours Intro class will make or break you as a philosopher. It is a difficult semester, but at the end of it, you will know whether or not philosophy is your subject. She loves bonding with her students, and if you play your cards right, she may sheepishly tell you about her boyfriend(s).

My favorite class in my first semester.  There's great class discussion.  I've had the most contact with Prof. O out of all my professors: she has lunches with us, meets us to look at outlines for essays, or makes time to meet if we don't understand something.  The class is a lot of fun.  I've learned to build strong arguments.  Yay for philosophy!

Obdrzalek is an absolutely amazing professor. She is wicked smart and very demanding, but she geniunely cares about the sucess of her students. Very accessible outside of class, she made it a point to have lunch with her students after class at least once a week. This calss was the most fun academic experience I have had at CMC, a must take.

Despite her last name being impossible to pronounce, Professor O is amazing!  She's incredibly smart and loves talking to students.  She usually eats with lunch with students and is always willing to give advice.  A lot of fun, but very difficult.  She rightly demands a lot from students, but she expects the right things.  If you're able, take her!

Nice professor. Very helpful outside of class. She prefers to meet with students before they write papers. She's somewhat demanding, but she's very enthusiastic and is always incredibly well-prepared for class.

One of the worst teachers I have ever had in my existence as a human being. She makes me wants to ****ing curse. The material was interesting, and the discussions could have been interesting if they werent so interminably boring, and she wasnt so pretentious.  I would recommend this class to no one, ever, under any circumstances.

She teaches what is definitely the most difficult intro philosophy course on campus, but it is probably also the most rewarding.  She demands a lot from her students, but it is only because she really wants you to learn.  She is very helpful in office hours and is a fun person to talk to outside of class.  Not an easy grader, but a fair one.

I think you either love her style or hate it.  I loved it.  I think that it is genuinly one of the best philosophy classes I have taken.  It is hard, but not overly time consuming.  I would strongly recommend her class for phil majors or people interested in philosophical analysis.

Talks very very fast. Bring your laptop to class if you wish to get anything out of your notes. Abrupt personality, sometimes even mean. This is possibly an unnecessary defense mechanism for a being a new prof. However, she is obviously brilliant and respectable in that sense.

If you are taking Intro to Philo to just fulfill a GE, I'd look to another teacher. Her reading are very hard, her lectures are hard to follow, and she pushes the class way too hard. She also spends way too much time trying to argue against students and has on occasion as blantly put down a student for no reason.
She is very interested in her teaching. However her lectures are boring and the reading is dense.

Professor Kind's Fundamentals of Logic class was super interesting and unlike any writing-intensive class I had taken. To do well, I would recommend doing the homework (which was optional) and studying hard for every quiz and testyour final grade is calculated through total points. If you're struggling, she's really accessible during office hours.

Took an intro phil class with Professor Kind and it was decently engaging. The paper prompts were pretty difficult so I wish more time was spent teaching how to write a philosophy paper. Definitely seek her out in office hours (and come with ideas about your paper) as she'll really guide you if you want to consistently write A/A- papers.

Prof Kind knows her stuff, and is great at teaching it. The unfortunate thing is it seems people either get logic or they don't. For those that don't, she still is good, and works with them. For those that do, the class is a breeze. Overall, I really enjoyed the class, liked logic and proofs, and would take it again.

Professor Kind is amazing, and I highly recommend taking a class with her! She is absolutely brilliant, assigns interesting readings and does an incredible job fostering discussion. Her class was difficult but rewarding. I definitely recommend her, especially for Philosophy majors!

Her class is difficult and she expects a lot from you, but it's worth it. She doesn't collect homework, but do it if you want to pass. By far one of the most accessible professors on the 5C's, and she cares about each individual student's success despite her huge class sizes.

She front-loads her Metaphysics class to have some really difficult concepts at the beginning, but if you persist the class is really interesting overall. You have 9 papers (800-1000 words each), 1 group project @ end of semester. Grading is fair but not too tough, and she really loves the subject which makes class great to attend.

Prof. Kind's FHS class (Life, death, and meaning) is amazing. If you like philosophy at all this is a great class to take. She grades quite fairly, an average paper is a B, a good one is an A-, and an A is reserved for the really really good ones. The class has a lot of reading and 3 difficult essays, so its a bit of work.
Professor Kind made me really come to love philosophy and helped me learn to think in a new way. She is easily the best prof I've had at CMC. Definitely take her class

Wonderful teacher! She was clear about her expectations and was a wonderful discussion leader. If you go into office hours, she will bend over backwards to help you on your essays. Definitely one of the harder FHS classes but life, death, and meaning isn't an easy topic to talk about!

Great facilitator of discussions. It's easy to get away with not doing the readings, but they are pretty interesting and you'll get a lot more out of the class by doing them. Definitely go to office hours, she'll go over your papers and tell you what you need to fix.
kind is a motherly professor.

I've taken two classes with her, including Logic, and have enjoyed both thoroughly.  Thought I would hate logic but she made it seem bearable.  She has relatively high expectations, but is clear about what they are.  Very willing to help outside of class.  If you take advantage of this help when you need it, you should have no problem succeeding.
No Comments

She doesn't care what you think.  She just wants you to agree with her.  This goes for class discussion and papers and it is ****ing annoying.  The point of the class in her mind is to teach you how to arrive at the correct conclusions, which she determines.  Not the point of philosophy in my book.  It's fine if you don't mind pandering to the her
Wonderful class, great books and the topics made me question and think about the subject matter.

I just don't like this class. I don't think she teaches philosophy very well. She's too concerned with definite facts and logic and not substance. And the papers topics are just plain horrible. And she doesn't facilitate discussion well.
great prof! very organized lectures and discussions. Keeps the discussions on topic, so they don't wander off. Very knowledgeable prof and just great class overall. Definately do recommend!

Excellent balance of discussion and lecture.  If the students are into the class, it will be very interesting.  A normal amount of reading and paper writing.  Grades decently but definitely does not hand out easy "A"s.
She's a really sweet, funny lady, and she's helpful outside of classes. I found her lectures a little hard to follow sometimes, though.

I thought I'd have an impossible time with this course, but Kind got me excited enough to want to *earn* the A. Kind has a great personality and kept an entirely procedural course rather entertaining.
Great course, not too difficult if you do ALL of the homework and pay attention in class. Amy Kind is "kind."

She was funny and very competent. The work was difficult, but I never felt overloaded with homework. She didn't take crap from the annoying, overly-confident boys in the class. Her tests are challenging, but she has really helpful study sessions before them all.
She made this otherwise complex subject pretty easy and even interesting. Her class is what introduced me to Philosophy, and now I am majoring in it. That says a lot.

(This is for Math 165) The entire class is lectures with low amounts of student participation. She provides thorough lecture notes with searchable text. The homework is more tedious than difficult but I think that might just be the nature of numerical analysis. There were three midterms but she grades generously and offers correction opportunities.

Prof Kao showed a ton of compassion during the online semester. She always made herself available outside of class and her usual office hours, offering students the chance to submit test corrections as well. If you're looking to learn Linear Algebra without the stress of not knowing whether you can get an A, I would take Prof Kao's class.

Prof Kao is great. While remote, she held multiple office hours every week to help with homework, and was super accessible outside of class. She also recorded all lectures and posted lecture notes which was very helpful. This class was not easy, but it was possible to do well, and test corrections were available. Cons- hard to understand at times.

professor kao is awesome! she's super nice and always tries to be available outside of class for help. she isn't amazing at explaining things, but you can she genuinely cares about your understanding. tests are also very similar to the homework, which there isn't much of.

I like that she is available to students and tries to be understanding and accommodating! But the class was not engaging and I didn't end up learning very much because the class didn't make me want to work for it. She has an agenda that she doesn't want to stray from so we often went ahead in the syllabus despite feeling lost.

Professor Kao is very helpful in and out of the classroom. Her differential equation class is lecture-based but she will try to get everyone to answer questions and get involved. She gives detailed explanations to theorems and definitions and she is open to questions. Homework is a lot and tough but pretty helpful. Definitely will take again!

Her lectures are not very clear and she is not good at explaining problems. Homework is assigned for every class and it is graded. She emphasizes learning definitions of concepts and tedious proofs, which are very unnecessary. However, she is accessible outside of class and tries to accommodate students. Tests questions are similar to hw problems.

It was a bit weird taking Prof Martin's class as one of my first upper div phil classes, as the syllabus is very structured and rigid in terms of what students can talk about. She'll often guide discussion in a very narrow direction, or will let students ramble on tangents that make it hard to engage. She cares, but I rarely got timely feedback.

Her class doesn't really feel like a philosophy class. She's overly formulaic and she generally expects you to interpret things the same way that she does. She also lets students who are clueless talk too much. Both of these things can make her class boring at times. That said, she's smart and not a bad professor... she just has some weaknesses.
The class didscussiin was great and shes really cares about her students

Prof Kreines is amazinghe has a real commitment to make the classroom environment and his pedagogy as inclusive as possible, and does his best to simplify the complex concepts that are part of his class. He has gone above and beyond his duties as a professor, even sending me additional readings outside of class that connect to my discussion posts.

Very thoughtful person who pushed me to become a better thinker and a more competent philosophy student. Some of the reading is difficult but Kreines makes a serious effort to make sure everyone is following along. Definitely one of the most intelligent professors I've ever had and I'm seriously considering having him as my thesis reader. Dope guy!

Hardest Phil class I have taken to date. Krienes really pushes you for your best, and expects a lot from his students. I really respect him and think he was a great (and hilarious) teacher. However, this class was also really tough. Made me think a lot about my own beliefs.

I have nothing but positive things to say about Professor Kreines. He's a phenomenal professor and if anyone is deciding whether or not they should take a class with him, the answer is 100% yes. Especially if you're interested in philosophy, he's probably the best professor you'll have.

Kreines is the best professor I have ever had. He made me fall in love with Philosophy. I am in my second class with him and can't recommend him enough. There are two papers and two exams per semester and his goal is to help you write the best papers you can and learn as much as you can. Not easy but 100% worth it.

I took FHS and Kant with Kreines, and I must say they are by far the best courses I've taken. Kreines not only teaches philosophy, but also hones the skills how to think in philosophy. He really pushes you on papers, but that doesn't mean you can't get good grades, and definitely not the reason not to take his class!!!

Truly brilliant scholar and fantastic at helping you make sense of the toughest pieces of philosophy. He doesn't mess around when it comes to grades, but if you meet with him early he can be extremely helpful. He really wants you to write the best paper you possibly can, and usually he's pretty good at getting that out of you.

Can't imagine how inspirational this class is to my life!! The intellectual challenge encountered and the effort spent in the course materials will train you to become a better thinker, both academically and in life. Yet you MUST WORK HARD to achieve a good grade in his class, no other way around. Ready to do Kant and Hegel under his instruction.

Kreines is the best. I honestly can't stress this enough: take his class. He is challenging but understanding. So smart and chill. I just want to take his classes all the time. Do your reading and pay attention in class and you'll have a really good time int he discussion.

The most fun and interesting class this semester. I loved the discussions in and out of class with this professor and the rest of the class. The prof really appears to respect every student and takes all arguments very seriously.

Professor Kreines is awesome. He sincerely cares about you and your thoughts--he's the type of person to get at the content rather than focusing on how you frame it or other trivial things. I got excellent grades but there is so much more to his class than that. You get to see different perspectives and cool insights.

FAVORITE PROF I've had this semester. Such a brilliant prof and is so engaging. I looked forward to almost every single class and have never been so intellectually engaged and stimulated. Kreines makes you into such a good writer who can construct tight arguments, and really pushes you to bring our your personal best. Would recommend to anyone.

Kreines is a good professor but not 10/10(!!!!!!!!).  Discussions are good & well-led.  Office hours can be a little confusing.  His brain moves much faster than most, so it can be hard to follow what he's saying in office hours.

He has high expectations for your work, but is more than willing to help you get there. He is super passionate about what he's teaching, and clearly brilliant. You must do the reading for this class, and expect reading responses before each class. Tests are reasonable.

Great professor and super helpful during office hours. His class is a little confusing because he bounces around topics a lot. However, he gives out handouts every class that summarize what he is trying to say. These are great. Assigns responses to readings every class which are a bit of a pain but not too bad. Would definitely take his class!

He was my favorite class for that semester.  His class discussions are challenging and that is where it pays off to pay attention, although you don't have to.  He has a good sense of humor and kept the class fun. The way he presents topics and talks about them often blew my mind about philosophy.  A great teacher to have.

HE IS AWESOME! I love Prof Kreines he really cares about his students and is such a great guy. He made me a better writer and I can argue my points with clarity now. Yes he could be hard but in the long run it is worth it because you can improve as a student with him. Take his class!

Although I had not noticed while sitting in his class, early modern has changed the way I look at the world and has challenged the foundations of everything from knowledge to causality. I highly recommend Krienes. He will make you a better writer and a better arguer, though it comes with the cost of a challenging class and a tough grading system.

Kreines is awesome! He's super smart, very fun and funny, and a great discussion leader. He expects a lot out of you, especially on essays, but he'll go over your drafts and edit them for you. You have to do the reading, but his class literally changed the way I look at the world. He really cares about you learning too. Take his class if you can!

If you're interested in pursuing a career in psychiatry, I HIGHLY recommend taking Orgo with Joel Mackey.  By the end of the class, you will have expertise in dealing with people with personality disorders.

Professor Mackey kept with the flipped classroom, which I personally did not find very helpful - especially with how difficult OChem is already. In class, he was laid-back and he's always willing to answer questions about class material. However, the weekly quizzes and exams were fairly difficult. Be prepared to put in a few hours each day.

Professor Mackey is great! This semester, his class stayed as a flip classroom. This still worked for me because in person, you do a lot of word problems which makes the readings and videos clearer and gives you a sense of how exam questions will look. Hes also good at explaining things and actually has humor.

Mackey teaches by intimidation. He likes to present himself as an abstruse academic who understand things his students do not. I did not find his office hours very helpful or his teaching style effective.
He's great! Very helpful in office hours

Mackey is a great choice for an o-chem prof. The class is hard, but that's mostly because of the material rather than his teaching style. He is really kind, approachable, and understanding. You can tell he cares deeply about his students. Highly, highly recommend him.

Professor Mackey's could be a little clearer in lecture. Often he gives a lot of examples but doesn't really explain the grand scheme of things. He's got a good sense of humor though and is very helpful outside of class. His tests are fair, but a lot of learning is done outside of class, as is expected with Organic Chemistry.

Mackey's lectures can be soothing to the point of sleep, but he has great OH and is actually really funny. He pretty much just goes over the book which is too bad, but he knows his stuff. His exams are either easy or hard... rarely in the middle which is hard to predict! Solid choice for a professor. WAY better than most new profs. Fun for lab too
Professor Uvin is vert knowledgeable and I would take his class again

Love Uvin! He is an engaging and fair teacher. Classes are discussion-based and you get out what you and your classmates put in (reading and effort-wise.) He has an approach of lots of little projects as opposed to larger, more stressful, papers and projects. I developed a real depth of knowledge, had fun, and felt overall very supported.

Professor Uvin is great! I really enjoyed his class and it was most definitely the best class I took this semester! He's funny, approachable, and very knowledgeable in his field of study. If you do take his FHS, make sure to do the readings for each class, or you'll be quite confused in class. Also, make sure to talk to him outside class.

I don't know why Prof. Uvin has low reviews for his freshman seminar courses, but in his area of interest, he's amazing. Funny, knowledgeable, and super accessible -- I'd definitely take another class with him, because I learned a lot and enjoyed it the whole way through.

Professor Uvin is one of the worst professors I have ever had. His feedback is rude, unhelpful, and downright degrading. He belittles his students and makes you second guess your abilities. He assigns way too much reading and classes are boring, not engaging, and hard to follow. He grades papers easily, but grades group projects extremely hard.
This class had really long readings and class was not super engaging or exciting. Prof also gives very critical feedback that isn't always super helpful.

The class consists of very long readings and it is a discussion based class. The professor provides very rude and unacceptable feedback; the feedback consists of insults rather than constructive criticism.

Uvin (former Dean of Faculty which is why he has so few ratings) is amazing! It's about development. Participation, 2 short papers (very easy), a class that you plan (pretty easy), and a longer final paper (easy bc lots of time to do it). Interesting, not long readings, and the papers are analyzing interviews and data. Highly recommend this class!

She is pretty lecture heavy, but the content was interesting and she keeps the class engaged with plenty of time to ask questions if you're confused. The problem sets could be tricky sometimes, but she's willing to help if you ask.

Professor Finseth is really nice and her class was great! Problem sets are tricky but shell offer a lot of help on them during office hours so definitely go to that. Classes are mostly lecture but her lectures are engaging and theres a lot of opportunities to ask questions.

Professor Finseth is an amazing professor who is caring and considers DEI in STEM. She is very lecture heavy, but her lectures are very clear and concise as long as you listen and come to class. The tests are somewhat tricky but very doable; plus, she will give you opportunities to have some help during exams!

Such a good prof. Her lectures are really clear and she presents topics in a very visual format which make them easy to understand. It is definitely a fast-paced class and the tests cover a lot of material, but she will walk you through every problem set in office hours and is really kind and helpful.

Awesome Professor, really cares about her students and her office hours are a must. She's super helpful with answering questions and as long as you are engaged in her class and actively participating you'll be fine. Office hours are super helpful especially with the problem sets assigned. Tests are fair, you need to know the material to do good.
Professor Findley was a great professor! Her lectures were very useful as she used both PowerPoints and the whiteboard. I learned a lot from her, and her problem sets and tests were fair.

If you read over the textbook before lecture, you should be fine. The problem sets are definitely challenging but if you go to office hours (she has multiple every week), you should be able to get 100 on every problem set. The tests are not unreasonably difficult and if she feels that anything has been given unfairly may offer extra credit.

While it's true that the lecture can go a little fast at time, the slides are online so you can easily review them. She holds weekly problem-solving sessions, and if you attend them and/or OH, you can easily get 100% on your homework (and actually learn what you're doing from it). I found the class straightforward and would generally recommend.

Findley is a really nice person but a pretty horrible professor. Her lectures are really fast, it's difficult to keep up with her in class and she tends to read right off of the majority of her slides but her powerpoints are always posted before class. Problem sets were tough and problem solving wasn't always helpful. Definitely go to office hours.

She's a very nice lady outside of class, but her lecturing style is terrible. She is extremely vague in her lecture slides, and the weekly problem sets are a nightmare. She goes very, very fast and skims over things but then later tests you heavily on really difficult problems she didn't even go over in class. I wouldn't recommend her for Genetics.

One of my favorite professors so far! Class was focused less on grades and more on learning, so I could spend time actually exploring the content. Lectures were clear and concise. If you asked a question in class, the answer was sometimes confusing; however, he was always self-aware and took time to email clarifying, comprehensive explanations.
Loved Professor Chandrangsu for bio lab! Clear expectations, very helpful, and the class improved my lab skills and science writing skills a lot

Nicest & most chill prof I've ever had, loves bio so much and is super easy with course requirements. Little work outside of class, as we were online he made everything open note/open source so tests were pretty easy. Sometimes he didn't give the best explanations or go in depth but it's just an intro course. highly recommend :)
Generally easy-going professor who lacks the ability to explain concepts clearly.

Kind enough guy who tries and cares but did not feel that he explained class concepts or in-class activities clearly, which was frustrating. Struck me as being more of a researcher than a teacher. Exams were mostly fair with one or two questions that did not appear anywhere in the reading or in lecture. Did not feel inspired taking this class.

Prof. Chandrangsu is incredibly kind. He teaches well, gives little work outside of class, discusses interesting concepts, and prepares you for the exams solidly. I have yet to take an exam for his class and not feel confident and ready. He is a fairly tough grader, but the exam material is straight forward and there are never any curveballs

I really liked his personality + dedication to his students. For example - he knew all of our names almost instantly, even though there were over 50 of us in intro econ. However, I do think the material was way too hard for an intro econ / required GE class. I worked super hard - and received an average grade. Great guy, super hard exams + quizzes.
Honestly incredibly knowledgeable in his field but not a class worth taking especially at an intro level- quite a deterrent for prospective econ majors.
Good teacher but extremely hard tests given that it is just an intro / GE class.

Fernholz was a very solid teacher. We had a short quiz every week and the class was mainly lecture/PowerPoint-based. There was a good amount of homework every week as we had to watch multiple videos and take notes which were very time-consuming. Fernholz makes you work for the grade. It is not easy, but he is very helpful and a good prof overall.

Prof. Fernholz is a fantastic professor. Econ50 is a class with 40+ people yet it never feels that big -- he will always take the time to get to know you and help you. Econ50 can be hard yet he explains everything extremely well, though you will need to work. For a compulsory class like 50 -- there isn't a professor better than him.

Prof. Fernholz just reads off the slides which you have access to on Sakai so you don't really have to show up. The course is test heavy and he doesn't curve so your overall grade is the averages of your tests, basically. Although, he is helpful during office hours and cares about his students.
Really great professor. Cares about whether his students understand the material conceptually; which is all that you really want out of econ 50.

Tests and quizzes are very difficult and you need to self-teach/learn a lot and he doesn't curve. He basically reads slides that are the assigned reading and the class is pretty boring. Unless you've taken econ before, this class will be very challenging.
Great class!

Fernholz is a great guy. Very light on math, but HEAVY on conceptual thinking (which is harder than it seems if you have never taken Econ before). Little homework, but the tests are difficult, and his curve system is helpful for those doing really poorly but not ones in the middle. I would recommend his class, but it will likely not be an easy A.

Ok professor. Moves kind of fasts in lectures and does not always explain concepts clearly. Tests include problem types never seen before. Office hours are not super helpful. Good news is he uploads PPTs so you can review.

For a lecture-type class, there was lots of class discussion and he made the material seem really easy. It also helps that he uploads the lecture notes online if you have to miss class. He's super nice and the midterms and finals are exactly like the homework assignments.

One of the best professors at CMC! He is one of the most clear lecturers and relays the information very thoroughly. Easily accessible outside of class through office hours and emails. Each test and quiz are fair to the content.

Fernholz is a very clear and reasonable professor. His lectures are always neat, detailed, and available for us. No mandatory reading, 4 homework assignments, a few small reading assignments, 3 quizzes, 2 midterms, and a final exam. He curves heavily on the people at the bottom and lightly on the people up top. Work hard, and you can earn an A.

Hands down my favorite professor at CMC. His Econ 50 class is light on math but heavy on conceptual understanding, and he manages to make the material interesting. Super helpful in office hours. Highly recommend his classes.

Prof Fernholz is a super clear lecturer. He is great for Econ50 because he makes sure his students understand the material. He goes by the textbook and gives practice midterms.  I  would definitely recommend him for someone who has never taken Econ before (like me)

Professor Fernholz is a great prof! He was sooo helpful. He will let you come into his office any time and answer questions for pretty much as long as you want. Additionally, his tests align with the book so as long as you study the book you will be fine. This class was not a walk in the park but with hard work success is very attainable.

Fernholz is the man! He keeps math simple (great for IR majors who need macro). He is super helpful in office hours with problem sets and before exams. Workload is totally manageable and realistic. Take Macro with this guy!
Great Professor! Very clear with ideas and examples, explains really well. The pace of the class is just right. Keeps math easy and concepts detailed.

Fernholz is the boss. His teaching method is fairly consistent with the book he uses and tries to teach everything in context to the real world. He keeps the math simple which has its drawbacks but makes the class fairly easy.

Livesay was a solid teacher. The class was not insanely hard. The readings were very long and unreasonable, and the class got boring with discussion at times, but he was a good teacher overall. It is a very chill class, and can get a solid grade with minimal effort.

Dr. Livesay is a gem to the Claremont Colleges. I found so much value in the way he approached such a heavy subject - my favorite part of this course was the open discussions and the care and insight he shows for his students. He is very helpful in office hours and genuinely cares about his students.

Professor Livesay literally turned me into a History major. He exposed me to a completely new perspective in thinking about history critically. He is super willing to help you out and gives off big dad vibes (with occasional dad jokes). In short, take this class.

Very kind and respectful professor. The class had 5 papers with a final 10+ research paper on a topic of choice (don't worry, there was plenty of time for it). You select which reading assignments to write about for papers. No quizzes/exams. Most classes were discussion-based. Easy A or A-. Prof Livesay really cares about each student's success.

Prof Livesay is a caring and an effective teacher. I've popped by his office many times to just chat about history and etc. and he was always happy to oblige. I found the readings he assigned to be very interesting, as well as the assignments (a creative writing final paper). Great guy who's cares about his students and wants to see you succeed.

Livesay is extremely kind and responds positively to even the slightest extra effort by you.  His lectures are interesting, and he definitely notices participation.  Sometimes his grading was a bit unclear, but he is willing to go above and beyond to help you reach your goals.

He is very specific about what he wants in papers, and that generally includes a learning curve, but when you get the formula down it's not very difficult. Half the class is discussion based on the assigned reading and half of it is material he brings up in class. Great history prof and such a nice guy!

I thoroughly enjoyed Prof Livesay's class. He picks some of the most interesting and relevant readings and effectively incorporates them in his lectures and discussions. His grading is fair, and he's always open/willing to help. As with all history classes, there's a lot of reading but you could get by just by skimming. Highly recommend.

One of the worst teachers I've had. The class was mainly graded off of three extremely hard tests that had zero relation to what was taught. The test was 100x harder than the material that we covered. She also makes you do an insane amount of work outside of class. I do not recommend taking her for Stats at all! Not an intro-level course.

Worst profesor Ive taken a class with at CMC. Unprofessional, condescending, and her teaching style is very lazy. She makes you watch videos on your own, with some hard concepts and then goes over it in class. The assignments are time consuming and barely even help your grade cuz 75% is based on three tests.

Exams are tough and count for 75% of your grade, but Prof. Feitosa gives a lot of outside resources (TAs, QCL mentor, recorded lectures, extra assignments) that can be very helpful. She really wants you to succeed, but the exams count for way too much and are often graded pretty harshly.
Very hard class

Even though the class was online, Professor Feitosa made lectures engaging and also gave us an opportunity to get to know one another through fun activities. She does expect you to put in the work to earn the grade but is also readily available to help out in any way she can. Definitely recommend taking a class with her!
Feitosa is amazing! If you study hard, you will definitely get the grade you deserved! She was very accessible outside of class, so was the TA. Highly, highly recommend!

Locke is definitely the teacher you want to take for Philosophy GE. Short readings with a one-question quiz every day. Barely any homework. Don't have to take any notes. Cool dude. I 100% recommended it. The class has zero stress.

He's a very likable and enjoyable professor. I would highly recommend! Really interesting readings that are also very manageable. There isn't too much homework. He engages you in the class and sparked my interest in philosophy. He helps you grow as a writer and thinker. He's a pretty tough grader but if you put the work in he will reward you.

Readings every night, then a quiz on them in class. You have seven attempts to complete 4 writing assignments, all different. The class gets to choose their favorite philosophical topics to study in the second half of the semester. Most people get anywhere from an A to B-. Prof Locke is funny, gives great feedback, and loves to talk philosophy.

If you're looking to fulfill your Philosophy GE while improving your analytical writing skills this is the class. Prof Locke's levels system really pushes you to become a concise, analytical writer. If you listen take detailed note of his feedback between every attempt, you'll be fine.

Professor Locke's class had, by far, the most interesting readings of any course I have taken so far. If the idea of learning more about time travel or the free will debate interests you, take this course. He can be picky with writing assignments, but his goal is to make you a better analytical writer, not just let you coast through the class.

Dustin Locke was one of my favorite freshmen professors. I was very unsure about philosophy after some extremely boring high school classes, but I loved this class. I took his intro to reality and reason first semester and became a much better thinker, writer, and debater in that time. I recommend him to all my friends, and added him as an advisor

He grades on the level system so there are no midterms or finals, but the levels are definitely tricky and he can be very picky. The readings were SO interesting and I loved class discussions. If you go to his office hours he is very clear and it definitely helps! Overall a great prof with an amazing class but can be picky

Prof Locke was perfect for my phil GE. he's super nice, super helpful in office hours. Prepare for readings and easy quizzes about every class. his level writing system is tough but if you ask previous students to edit your attempt or give you their attempts, it'll help a lot!
LOVE this dude! He prepare you well for writing!

Professor Locke is so passionate about the material he teaches and makes everyone else passionate about it too. He gives daily reading quizzes about short readings, but I think they help to keep me engaged. He lets the class decide what we are going to learn for the second half of class and we talked about really interesting things. Take his class

Prof. Locke is super chill and he is always eager to answer questions or help. I love the class based learning and discussions and he genuinely loves philosophy and this makes it so much easier and funner to learn the subject!

I learned nothing in his class. Throughout, Locke was extremely unhelpful and seemed determined to make it as hard as possible for his students to do well. I have not yet encountered a worse professor, and I don't think I will.

This class is to philosophy what some kids talking about reality after watching Interstellar is to Immanuel Kant. Take this class if you heard the word philosophy somewhere but have no idea what it means and want to learn more. Don't take this class if you've ever actually seriously thought about any issue (or would like to).

Very fun class atmosphere. Lively discussion. Locke is very unique, as you will learn. He has a unique system for papers that I liked. He is a big fan of short papers. He very much facilitates discussion and supports students as they explore issues. He is great at summarizing arguments. Great use of your Philosophy GE.
